The one with the problem, Edward, Dorothy, Doctor, Bryan and Catherine. They are the ones to follow up and update us. The rest of us should message them personally. Thank you so much.

I am not the one who knows too much but apologies to anyone who is offended. Let it not become like a song about to be launched. One who keeps silent has nothing to regret. I sent a personal message to Nora apologizing though I haven't apologized to Isabella yet and others. I actually said all that in Nora's inbox not on the group. It means Nora should have replied to just me instead and not take it any further. That's called rumour mongering. Thanks.
I think Luke's advice ain't bad. I think we should be open to positive criticism and differentiate it from blame. That will work for us. May God bless you.

Thanks Mr. Luke but I was replying to Isabella and letting her know everything because she had seen it too. I forgave you like you asked me to. It's not like we were addressing only Francesca but we were discussing something that concerns us all. Something to do with sickness. It wasn't a secret. Usually when I need to talk to someone personally, I contact them directly. I did that because we all felt her pain in the group. I suggested in the beginning that we should be there for each other. What Francesca went through concerns us all so there was no need for personal messages. If we made a mistake, forgive us. And that goes to everyone else because it's not just me who did it like Isabella told you.

And it's not rumor mongering. I am an adult and a parent so I don't do that. I wanted to let my friends know the mistake we had done like you have heard Isabella say she's one of them. So for you who knows it all after giving your advice, I had to inform my colleagues who didn't know. Just change that because it's not rumour mongering and use a word that's more respectful. Hello I am slightly concerned. I am reading over the photo interviews and one vht felt that the cause of pus in the ear was when milk accidently got into the ear and when the wax becomes too much it turns into pus. This is not correct. Would one of the vhts kindly explain what causes pus in the ear?

Well done Bryan - I have been at Omni Med when you were not around. But on Wednesday I have an issue and might be late. But when I finish in time I will come earlier and join you. Because I am going to something important for our family. I must go to that meeting, but if I get out early I will join. That is why I came to the organisation to inform you that I might be late.

I think that pus in the ear is caused by bacterial and viral infections that affects the middle part of the ear So if the infection is too much the middle ear(ear drum)  may tear open causing that pus
Totally correct. Thanks Rachael
You are welcome Andrew

Hi Bryan, thanks for the work, I came at the Organization but I didn't find you, I wanted to inform you that on Wednesday I may be so late, we have a family meeting which is so urgent, but when they start earlier I will join you that is why I had come to let you know

Doctor well done, I have received the news from Edward that you will meet me tomorrow, I was asking at what time will you meet me tomorrow, I don't have network , but I request Catherine or Bryan to reply to me when am still in a place where there is network.

About the other issue of milk in the ear, the milk they are talking about does not drop direct in the ear, for us in Buganda, the milk can drop on the knees when the mother is breastfeeding the baby, that is when people say that the baby got some milk drops in the ear, that is an infection that started long time ago, but in our tradition we have people who treat this, (traditional healers) but when we go to the doctors they say its pus but it is an infection in most cases a child is born with it. Have a good night am Johnson Matthew

Still on the same issue, because this issue is so important, for us in Buganda we have traditional doctors who treat such an infection which can't be treated by other qualified Doctors, we have diseases which can't even be treated by white doctors  but when you use the traditional medicine you get healed, we have seen this for a long time but for us keep referring to medical doctors (bazungu) but we also have the medicine that heals that problem, it is an illness which sometimes fails to be healed by the qualified Doctors then they end up saying someone's ear has rotten yet it is an illness. That is my second explanation about this issue.

Greetings VHTs, welcome back from the meeting. But about this patient, X. The advice I can give to her mother after knowing the illness, acute otitis media. The advice I give her is to feed the child with the food which gives more energy because when the child is still young the body is weak. So the child needs more care. Covering her - feeding her and also giving her body building foods that can't be affected with the disease so the white blood cells can get more energy. That is my suggestion and idea and that is what I tell the mother. To give body building foods, beans, mukene (silver fish), soya, so that the body can have more energy and also that WBCs can be stronger. Thanks alot good night. I am your VHT Matthew, Makata.

Greetings members, thank you for all you are doing to see that we develop our community in Health, now there is a problem which may not be good to our coordinators, the way people are responding to questions is not encouraging. Some VHTs are not replying to cases for example like yesterday, I encourage you to respond to the cases and answer the question the way you understand it, because even if you are not right still in the evening we get the right answer, I also encourage you that whenever we get the answers let's go back to ours notes and remind ourselves about the issues we are learning about. I have understood that there is a book which will be put to show the way people respond to cases, so I don't know whether it will be showing the Marks and our performance, so I advise you all to be active. Another thing I am not sure about is whether Qiana receives her phone back but to those who have their phones, please let us use them to share ideas so that we can take this project ahead also to make our representatives happy, I know they were so upset yesterday. I wish you a good day.

Good morning ladies and gentlemen. Thanks for all the work you're doing. Today I want to talk to you about the issue of the files. I would like us to work together whether one received a file or not. The reason I am saying that is because some people received files with people they didn't treat or who don't stay in their areas. If someone sends a name of a person from their file that they didn't treat or who don't stay in their area, the one who knows them should help and direct that person. Today someone else may be having a file but next time it will be you. I suggest we work together to make this work easy because it's 30th and almost June. It will be bad if we look for those people without finding them yet someone who could be knowing them just didn't let us know. An example is yesterday when Edward asked who knew the patients he listed down. I am not sure if you sent him a private message because I haven't seen anyone directing him. I therefore suggest we work together so we can finish the work that was given to us. This is not about only those who got the file but everyone. I will be happy if we help each other and do this work very fast.

I would also like to remind those I will be moving with that I sent them an audio telling them we shall be meeting at the health centre developing a program. Please don't forget and keep time since what we shall be doing doesn't take much time. It could take less than an hour. If we keep time, we shall do what we are supposed to do and also go back and do other things. I remind you all that I sent private messages that today is the day we are meeting at 2pm. If there's anyone who would love to join us though they don't have a file, you're free to attend so we can share ideas and find out where our patients  stay. Thank you so much.

Thank you our fellow VHT who have shown us how you mix the ORS and the way it is given to the child, but just a reminder, a child of 6 months is given 1/2 zinc once a day for 10 days, a child of 7months to 5 years is given one zinc tablet for a day for 10days. The pack has 10 tablets. After giving the child zinc, they better for the child to breast feed so the mother gives the baby breast milk, even the other milk because zinc goes with milk. Thank you so much.
What I was meaning is that a child of 7 months to 5 years should be given one zinc tablet once a day for 10days. It was a mistake to say 7 months to 5months, I meant 5 years

Also VHTs. We have some schedule to inform you of. The final set of interviews with the cameras for any new photos and the final interviews about the project will be happening in the next two weeks. After this we will not do more interviews, since we know this process is long and also tiring but we thank you for your final effort.

The important dates are as follows:  Tuesday 25th June 2019: Interview with Dorothy and Edward (2pm at Seeta Nazigo HC III) Please bring your cameras. We will reimburse you 4000 for transport and your time. Wednesday 26th June 2019: Interview with Francesca and Matthew (2pm at OmniMed in Makata). Gordon at 3.30pm (OmniMed Makata). Please bring your cameras. We will reimburse you 4000 for transport and time.  Thursday 27th June 2019: Patricia  AND Luke (2pm SEETA NAZIGO) 4000 SHILLING REIMBURSEMENT. MONDAY 1ST JULY 2019: Nora AND Karl - 2pm SEETA NAZIGO HCIII. 4000 SHILLINGS. WEDNESDAY 3RD JULY 2019: Isabella AND Harriet 2pm - SEETA NAZIGO HCIII. 4000 SHILLINGS.

We have a celebration day, awards ceremony and workshop to celebrate the project on the THURSDAY 11TH JULY 2019. You are all invited with one guest. Lunch and transport provided. Certificates will be awarded. We will host this in the new main building at OmniMed and celebrate it's opening at the same time. Invites will be given out at the interviews in the next 2 weeks. Please nominate a spokesperson who will give a 10 minute speech at the day.

Greetings VHTs, I read the information about the party we are having on 11th of July and also opening the new building, and you told us to come with one guest. But I suggest before we call anyone else, we should make invitation letters calling the Health workers like the in charge of Seeta Nazigo where we work from, we give them a chance, the Master of Ceremony I suggest we call a person called Dauda, most people call her "Dembe lya Museveni" (meaning the peace of Museveni) because she does her things very well, she will not make us stay hungry because most of the MCs make people stay hungry, I suggest we bring up ideas on this issue.

I also thank you, thanks Luke for your advise, this function is going to be a good one, but it has some professionals of a higher level as I think, so I suggest we chose someone who can speak English whenever there is need and also speak Luganda, therefore Dauda can't do that work well, let's chose someone who can do this in that way it is supposed to be

thanks everyone for today's work, thanks for your ideas, Luke and Francesca, what Luke said about calling the Health workers of Seeta Nazigo is good, I suggest we don't  ignore that. About the master of ceremony, this function was not organized by the VHTs, it was organized by Andrew and his team, so they know the master of ceremony that they arranged for the function, even if Andrew told us to chose the master of ceremony, still he would tell us to chose among the VHT who know about the project as he said so let's leave that issue for Andrew and his team that he works with. Thank you so much.
I also thank you supervisor for being nice and polite, we shall chose someone amongst ourselves to make a speech, that is easy. It takes only one day

I also greet you all, thanks for the work, am asking something small, as we are going to have our celebrations and because there are some visitors who are going to be invited, as VHTs, what will be our dressing code, shall we be given new uniform to show that we are different or everyone will dress as he or she wishes, thank you.

Thank you for clarifying, you have done well, the first thing Luke said about the Master of ceremony was wrong, that person will be chosen by Andrew, for us we shall chose a spokesperson to give a speech , we shall select one person among the VHTs, so most of you got it wrong, I know English is not easy not easy so most of you didn't get it well, but that's how I understood it. Thank you!

My reply to the first question is - first take the history of the patient, then you examine the ears and test the hearing. Then question B. You write the history on the form that was given to us, then question C. Name of the patient, sex, age, and how long they have been having the problem.

It is me Harriet. I welcome the person then thank her for bringing the child to the hospital or health center. After that I introduce myself as a VHT. I then tell her everything about the patient. I take her consent and then begin asking her about the child. I then ask for permission to check the child's ear. Part B. I write the history in the book that was given to us, then I give her one copy and take one to the health center. Part C. I ask who the head of the house hold is, her name, then the name of the patient, then the age of the patient, where she stays, the date, which ear has the problem. Then I ask about the other patients in the household. I then ask if she has any other disease aside from ears. That is my answer to the question.

This is my reply to the question. The first thing I do is to give the mother the consent forms. After she has signed them it means I have permission to examine the child. After signing I also sign to show that I am the one in charge of treating her. After that I introduce myself to her, tell her I am part of a project that is helping people with ear problems. After all that I ask for permission to touch her child's ears. After that I ask for her permission to write down the questions I ask about her child as I write in the book. I ask for her name, the name of the child and the age of the child and I write them down. I also write the village where she comes from plus the date and which ear has the problem. After that I check the hearing.  I ask her to put the child on the lap so that I can examine her. When I examine I the ear first which does not have the problem. If I find that the ear has a problem I give the child pain killers if I have them. If I don't - I refer the child. I note the problem with the ear in my book. In case I give the patient the pain killers and there is no change I follow up again and refer the patient
Please forgive me. I didn't reply to the question because my battery was dead. I have the solar charger but there was no sunshine. By the time I checked it was too late for me to answer.

This is todays question.

You take the history. You ask if the child has had ear pain (otalgia). The mother says yes. She has also had discharge from the ear (otorrhea). She does not give any other symptoms. Next you look in the ear. Describe what you see and tell us what you think the diagnosis is?
Please reply to the question for today.

This is Luke. This is my answer. You wash out then after you dry. Then you examine again. If it is still not clean I do it again. But if it is clean enough I tell her to go and follow up after some weeks.
When I wash the ear and it is clean I tell the person to then come back so I can follow them up. I also advise the mother, how to make tissue spears to dry the ear until the child hears.
When I look into the ear I can see pus in the ear canal and a perforation in the ear drum. The disease is called otitis media.
Members how are today?. Have you seen the question? Answer it.

My answer to the question for day before. First introduce yourself to the mother of the child. Then you ask who the head of the house hold is. The age of the child. The village. Before asking her to examine the ear of the child, you enquire which ear has the problem. Whether it is one or both. After examining and you find the ear has a problem you give the child pain killers. You check again in 3 days. If there is no difference you refer the child.
When I look in the ear I can see perforation and pus coming from the middle ear. The disease is called otitis media.
When I look in the ear canal or ear drum I see pus. The disease is called otitis media. When I go to her home….
What I forgot to write about was putting ear drops on the patient. You have to do 3 drops, 3 times a day. They have to keep doing this until the ear heals.
Thanks for your participation VHTs. Keep the answers coming like Herbet said. We will provide the correct answers in the morning.

After washing out the ear I put antibiotics in (3 drops). The other thing I forgot is that the disease is called otitis media.
Sorry I had forgotten to give the name of the disease, but it is called otitis media.

QUESTION 3. The mother asks what treatment you could give the child. Tell us what you would do.
Its me Harriet. I can see the child's ear has pus. And the disease the child has is called otitis media. That is what I see, but I have just seen this so that is why I am replying now.

I greet you all fellow VHTs. It's me Nora and this is my answer for today's question. First of all, I clean the boy's ear using antiseptics, then I dry it, after I give him antibiotic drops to kill bacterial germs. That's how I've answered today's question. Have a good day.

I greet you all fellow VHTs. I am called Patricia and thanks for the work you're doing. I was unable to answer yesterday's question because I saw them late and my phone's battery was down. The treatment I would give to the mother for the child are anti bacteria drops.

I first explain to the boy's mother the treatment I can give including ear wash out, drying, pain killers and then antibiotic drops.
The treatment I can give the child is ear wash out, dry mopping, then three drops of antibiotic ear drops three times a day for 5 days as I do follow up.
The treatment I can give is ear wash out with iodine and water. After that I dry mop and then I re check to see if there's still pus. If there's no more pus, I put antibiotics.
What I do for that mother is to give her antibiotic drops to be put in the boy's ears i.e. three drops three times a day for seven days. After 7 days I follow up.
I do ear wash out and dry mopping then I give 3 drops of antibiotics 3 times a day for 5 days and I the follow up.

1. Some patients are reluctant to go to government health centers as they feel they will be charged money to be seen even though it is mean to be free. How can you as VHTs address this issue? 2. Why do you think children in poorer areas have higher chances of getting Chronic Supportive Otitis Media than those in richer areas?3. Does anyone have any questions or did they not understand anything?

I will start with the second question, the reason as to why people who are poor normally get chronic supprativr otitis media is that in most cases poor people have no money to take them to the Health centre to get assessment and also treatment, that's why they end up using sticks when they've got a lot of wax in their ears, some stay in pain not knowing even where to go to get help, now like a disease for sickle cells in some places they offer free treatment but because of lack of transport to take them where there is free treatment, they get affected. Therefore they lose hope, even in Seeta Nazigo Health Centre, they may be offering free dental services but a poor person even fails to get 5000 shillings to bring him or her for treatment which is not the case which the rich.

Am Luke still on question number one, I will start by giving an example that when a fish rots, it starts from the head so the problem started in Mulago the biggest hospital where Doctors could say "those who came with something in the pocket where are you?" meaning only the patient with money is the one who is able to meet the doctor, so those who don't know the "money language" are left to suffer.

Therefore up to now people have that feeling the when you to any Government hospital without money, you won't get treatment so they fear staying in a line and at the end of the day they are not worked upon, but a rich person just goes  once and fast. People end up regretting for example pregnant mothers who go for antinental care and those who take their children for immunization, they say they wish they had money so that they can pay and be worked on fast like in a private health centre. I think it could be so easy if we had that system where we have enough doctors in health centres, this can save time and people will stop thinking of paying for the treatment, that's my view as Luke

Well-done everybody, am Jane, my point is that some patients don't want to go to the government Health Centres because they fear wasting a lot if time yet they don't get the medicine because free things normally are on demand by very many people yet the medicine is not enough for us. The answer to the second question is the reason why we get such diseases is because people don't maintain hygiene especially for their kids, and so the children grow even without cleaning their ears, they grow with a lot of wax which ends up affecting the middle ear, that's my view, but I also have a question, what brings otitis media in children?

Greetings to you all, the first question is a two way question which needs answers but also discussion according to people's opinions, paying money in hospitals used to be there some time back so people still have a thinking that when they go to the health centre they'll be asked to pay for treatment so people fear to even tell the health officers that they don't have the money yet the medicine is available for the second time as a VHT, what I could do is to inform the patients that there is medicine so that they can go there and that its free of charge, I also get a chance since  always at the Health centre to inform them whenever the medicine is out of stock and I tell the patient according to the illness to go to another Health centre where there is medicine.

Let me emphasise this. At the government health center there is some medicine that is not offered. Someone comes with a condition and sits from morning to evening. And later on when they see the health worker, they tell them they don't have that medicine and tell them to get it elsewhere. People think medicine is there, but it is just not there.

I think people in villages are prone to such diseases because of the conditions they live in. People cannot take good care of their children. They don't check their ears as they don't know about the problems it causes. This leads to disease like the one we talked about -  CSOM. I also have a question - what is the biggest cause of CSOM, especially amongst us?

The second question consists of too much poverty which is so high among the people so they can't afford to get the needs even the treatment, another view is that most people are so reluctant, it may also be due to ignorance whereby even if you have money and you are not aware of what to do, it becomes another problem, another issue they fear confronting the people due to status, they think they are high professionals who may take them as illiterates or people of a low status.

Others believe in witchcraft, where they get cheated of their money thinking that they were bewitched, if there was medicine at the health centre to cure the illness before it worsens, I think it could save people from going in referrals.

The second question, children from poor communities are prone to chronic supprative otitis media because poor people don't receive enough health services. Others have little understanding on health issues. Lastly, I request the teachers to explain to us the meaning of the word allergy.

Greetings to my fellow VHTs. As a VHT, this is  the way I can handle a patient who is reluctant to go to a government health facility because they're afraid they will be asked for money. I would encourage them to go there and assure them it's for free. I would also tell them to let me know if a health worker asks for money, so I can report them to the DHO and to prevent the vice.

Greetings to my fellow VHTs. As a VHT, this is  the way I can handle a patient who is reluctant to go to a government health facility because they're afraid they will be asked for money. I would encourage them to go there and assure them it's for free. I would also tell them to let me know if a health worker asks for money, so I can report them to the DHO and to prevent the vice.

This is my answer to question 2. I think the reason as to why our children contract otitis media is because some parents are not hygienic. Some parents don't care. They fail to buy soap therefore the children go to bed without bathing. Sometimes they ask them to do it themselves. This is a 4year old who won't care about cleaning the ears. That's my view as Nora.
For the third part, my question is what causes allergy? Greetings to you all and I wish you well as you attempt those questions. May God be with us and bless us.

I  am Isabella Kizza. People don't want to go to government health centres because their health workers don't care about patients. I think you all remember during the training the lady who almost died from there just because she was lacking water. That's the reason people would rather pay money in a private clinic where they care.

Why are children from poor communities prone to that disease? In the past, that disease wasn't taken seriously. Maybe those who have money knew about it. You see, even at our health centre there's no specialist to treat it. You find that a poor parent cannot take their child for examination because they don't have the ability.

As Gordon, this is my answer. Patients are reluctant to go to government health centres not because they are asked for money but because of long queues. They spend a lot of time waiting in line and after fail to receive the medicine. They're instead sent to get it from clinics. Another issue is the government health workers who happen to be very tough. Also, patients are given under dose. That's what stops them mostly. For the second question, children who grow up in village families don't get medical check up so they end up getting problems. On the other hand, their counterparts from town families tend to have rich families therefore receive enough care and medical check up. Most rich families are found in town. That's my view as Gordon.

This is my answer to the first question as Harriet. Some people are reluctant to go to the health centres because they're asked for money which is true. Much as they do ask for it, the government facilities have no medicine. You can only find it there once in awhile. Another reason is they take long to attend to the patients. Some patients can be very ill and decide to sleep around the health centre but when the nurses arrive they insult them instead. Some nurses are very rude but very good ones are there too.

As Harriet, I think children from poor communities are prone to diseases because some people don't take certain issues seriously. They know even if they find out about them, there's nothing much they can do. If at all they fail to get salt and eat food without salt! That's why some get knives and commit suicide. Therefore, if something is not preventing one from eating or drinking, it's not an issue. That's why poor children are affected because of need.

For the third part, my question is why is it that amongst the diseases we are examining, women are the most affected. I don't get it. Thanks for participating, supporting and doing good work. God bless you.
How are you Andrew? Thanks for the work. Thanks for training us.

Andrew thanks for the work it is Harriet. Thanks for what you are doing for us. Thanks for not giving up on us Catherine and Bryan. Thanks for the responsibility. We really appreciate. Thanks for doing this project. There are so many people who have ear problems, but you have been able to help them. Even though some are still doubting I am sure they will get to know the project will help them.
I have a concern as Gordon. When you talk to patients about allergies, they don't understand. What is allergy? Does it mean changes in the body? I'd like to know it in our language.

Thank you my fellow participants. People don't go to the government health centers because of the pain the have to endure. You have to wake up early to get there as soon as possible only for them to arrive at later hours. You then wait for long hours, and as you are finally about the get them, they break off for lunch. They then take long hours having lunch. If you have some little money you would rather go to a private clinic where you are more likely to receive immediate attention.

My apologies to you all. This is my response to the second question. Why are village children prone to ear diseases? We villagers have our own way of reasoning that is different from town people. First of all we have no time to clean our children's ears. Even when they get a problem we poison them more. We mix several herbs and end up introducing germs in their ear which causes inner ear diseases.

This is my view on the questions. Some people are just lazy, other government health centers don’t care about the patients which frustrates them making them go to private clinics instead. Others decide to just sit home and wait upon the Lord to finally take them away from earth. Also people in the villages are so lazy and don't check their children's ears. Others swim in dirty water. But thank you Andrew for that training. And his team Bryan and Catherine. Thank you so much. That is my view.
People don't go to the government health centers because of the long distances and medicine is never there most of the time. The other issue is about the time they take waiting for the nurses.

Children in villages get that disease because their parents don't seek advice on what treatment to give them. They instead go to witch doctors, instead of going to health centers. Those in urban areas have family doctors.

Thank you Luke. This is an interesting point. Indeed it probably does not help that poorer children are unable to afford quick and prompt treatment. Fast treatment for CSOM with washout, drying and antibiotic drops is important. It is also very important to follow up the child regularly. It is your role as VHTs and esteemed community members to act as advocates for the people. You know that medicine should be free at the health centers. We therefore need to apply gentle pressure to the government officials to make sure this happens.

Interesting. So you have to encourage people to challenge those who demand money. For example - everyone has a boss. Even the doctor at the health center.. their boss is the in charge, the incharges boss is the DHO... encourage people to know their rights as citizens and to challenge those who abuse power. Get them to take their name and registration number. Then report this to LC1 and HC in-charge in formal writing, keeping a copy for yourself which can be used as evidence.
All very interesting views. I think then as VHTs you should be advocating for the poorer members of society to ensure they are treated fairly.

Ok. Thank you Julliette. That is why keeping good records (as you are doing in your books) is important. That way we have a clear record of a. how many patients in the community have a problem b. using this evidence to petition the district and Health Center to show there is a need for good treatment and enough medicine.
If we have evidence and are informed citizens aware of our rights and the needs of those who we serve then we are empowered.

Thanks Jane. Otitis media is a disease of poor hygiene and actually much more common in poor children than those from rich families. For example, in poor areas of Australia almost 70% of children has CSOM compared to the rich areas where it is only 1%. It is a disease of inequality.  It is common in areas of overcrowding, poor hygiene etc. If a child is exposed to a dirty environment and put things in their ears then they have more risk of introducing bacteria...
This is excellent Edward. You are acting as an advocate for your community and as a leader informing people of their rights as citizens. Thank you for your hard work.
Very interesting points. Thank you for sharing Edward.

Thank you Karl . Very excellent points. To reply to your question - "allergy" means a reaction to something which the persons body is against. For example some people have allergies to dust which makes them cough, others are very serious such as some people are allergic to latex, nuts or cat fur.... there skins goes very itchy and swells up and they can even die if they have a very serious allergy.
Thank you Karl . This is excellent advocacy work and great citizenship.

I can understand their frustration Nora. That is why having the medicines as VHTs and going house to house is so important. You build trust and respect of the community like how you are doing with Anna Nabwire the 97 year old lady who you are treating with antibiotic drops. Imagine how hard it would be for her to go to Seeta Nazigo 3 times a day for treatment with drops. You are giving her an excellent service.
Good point. The cause of CSOM is due to poor hygiene sometimes so encourage parents to keep their children's ears clean and dry.

Am Patricia, its true that big government hospitals ask for money which is not the case with other small Health centres, therefore as a VHT, the knowledge I give people who are poor and who can't afford to pay is that they should go to the Health centres instead of staying home, because at the health centres there are professional health officers who will examine them and tell them which illness is affecting them so they can buy the medicine at a lower price after knowing the cause of the illness, that's my view.

The second question, my answer is that people have poor hygiene, parents don't care about their children very well, they have low income earnings, poor clothing , they even fail to buy soap because of low income, a child may even spend three days without bathing which had caused diseases like otitis media due to poor hygiene.

Nora. Please see my previous answer to Karl. This is a good question - allergy can be caused by lots of things. Sometimes the person is born with it, other times they develop it over time. No one knows the exact cause. What is important to know is that people can be allergic to lots of different things e.g. fur, dust, antibiotics, pollen, nuts, milk etc. The response also differs. For example some people have a minor reaction e.g. itching. Others have a very severe and dangerous reaction. Their lips swell up and their airway can close off. This more dangerous reaction is much rarer but important as the person can die.

Thank you for both answers Isabella. I appreciate this input. I agree - it is hard to find specialist ear doctors in Uganda. However you VHTs in Makata, Seeta Nazigo, Kavuule and Kirujja Butoke and now becoming experts in ear disease. You will be leaders for future VHTs and examples for other VHTs and Community Health Workers around Uganda and the world.

Thanks Gordon. This is true actually that poorer children get CSOM more. However there are also poor areas of towns where children suffer, especially in slum areas. The other big problem is timely treatment and also prevention. Remember, encourage adults to make sure their children don't pick at their ears, keep their hands clean and seek prompt advice and treatment if they have pus coming from their ear.

Thank you for all your inputs Harriet. You have done excellent work this last few weeks. I like how you are working in pairs with Isabella. It is a good idea and other VHTs might consider going in pairs on their home visit or asking their supervisor (Edward or Dorothy) to accompany them once in a while. In answer to your questions why are women getting disease more than men.... It is unlikely that women are more affected, but women might be more likely to be at home when you do home visits compared to men who might be out. Also women might be more willing to say they have a problem compared to men who many deny any problems. This is a very interesting insight though.

Good morning VHTs. Did you have a good weekend? Thanks for all your work. We are now back to our cases which we always have after 2 weeks.

Question 1. You are on a home visit in Kirujja Butoke and you are asked to see a 35 year old woman. She is complaining of hearing loss in her left ear, some discharge that has not settled and  pain. Q1a. What are the things you need to do? Q1b. Where should you record the history?Q1c. What questions are important to ask in the history?
My Dear VHTs. Have you understood the question?

A)  Introducing yourself. Seeking for their permission to examine their ear. If they accept I examine them and take their history. B) I take their history in the book. C) I ask for the head of the household. The number of the people in the house hold. Age. How long they have had to pain. If they got any treatment. If so which treatment. I wash their ear and given them antibiotics. After that I follow up.
Well done Miss Catherine. We have understood the questions but most of the VHTs are now in the garden planting because it rained. We have understood the questions and we shall reply. Thanks so much.
Ok Mr. Karl. Thank you.
Thanks very much Dorothy
The important question I ask after taking the history is if they have any allergy. That's what I have to say.

I write the history in the other big book that was given to us. I write down my names, head of household who signed the consent form and the names of the patient, their village plus everything concerning their ears. For example they told me they feel some pain, so I ask how long they've had it. After that, I ask them if they have any other disease besides ears. When I'm done with that, I embark on examination for the second time since I would have finished the wash out and given them some pain killers. I then check their hearing using the whispered voice hearing test. After that I give them a copy of the form to confirm that I have successfully treated them and then I take the pink one to the health centre. As for the white one, I write in it like Dorothy told us i.e. the phone number of the patient and where they stay to help me remember.

Question no.1) if I find that lady with pain and discharge, first thing I do is to give her some pain killers to reduce the pain. After that, I wash her ear. When I'm done washing her ear, I dry it. Next I put in antibiotic drops to heal the wounds. Three drops. I then let her go home. That's my answer to the first question. Question 2) I take her history but before that, I give her the consent form to confirm that she has accepted the treatment I will be giving her. I explain to her why she has to sign it. After accepting, I give her pain killers. When she says the pain has reduced, I do the ear wash out to remove the discharge. Next I dry it like I said in the first place. Another question, what important questions I'm I supposed to ask her. They include, how long she has had the pain, if she has had any treatment before and then I examine. After examining, I ask if she has any allergy. If she says she has, I call my bosses to inquire from them what to do like they told us.

Greetings to you all. When I go to see that lady in kirujja butoke, I first introduce myself to her i.e. Who I am and what I do. I ask her what she would like us to do because she may not want an ear wash out or she may want a specialist instead of me. I seek her permission and also explain to her that I can do it. When she grants me permission,  I examine her ears. If I discover there's discharge, I explain to her that we are going to wash those ears, dry them and then put antibiotics. Three drops three times a day for five days. I take the history in my book that has three sheets of carbon. When I'm done taking the history, I give her one copy and advise her to keep it. It helps me while doing follow up. I take another copy to the health centre and keep one in the book. After that, I ask for her names, the people who are apart of her household, her age, village, number of people in her household, how long she's had the condition and the treatment she's had so far. I ask her if she has any allergy. If she says yes, I request her not to use the medicine because it may cause complications. If she says no, I ask her to go ahead and use it. After 5 days, I go back to follow up.

Question 1a) I first introduce myself to the patient and then let her know what I'm going to do including taking her history, examining her ears and her hearing. I also seek for permission from the head of the household by signing the consent form. I then go ahead with the plan I just talked about. If I examine and find discharge in her left ear, I wash, dry it and then put antibiotic drops for about one week. b) I take the history on the form with three copies. One remains in the book, another is taken to the health centre while the other is given to the patient. c)The important questions I ask the patient as I take their history include her name, age, the ear with a problem , if her hearing is okay, if she has tinnitus, discharge, itching, pain or if they have any problem besides ears. That's my reply to the questions.

It's me Harriet. Greetings to you Catherine and well done. If I go to kirujja butoke and come across such a patient, I greet her then introduce myself to her. Once I'm done introducing myself, I ask her if she has any problems with her ears. If she says yes, I ask her if she would want to be examined. If she accepts, I write down her names, name of head of household, age, village and the ear with the problem. After that, I ask if she has any other problem besides ears. If she says no to that, I request her for some water to clean my hands. I then ask her again if I can examine her ears. If she accepts, I carefully take out my otoscope and examine her ears. In case I find her with that problem, I write it down and the particular ear I've found it. When I'm done with that, I check her hearing using the whispered voice test. If I find that her hearing is okay, I explain to her that I'm going to treat the ear with discharge. I then wash, dry the ear and give her antibiotic drops to use for five days, three drops three times a day. After the five days elapse, I go back to follow up. Also since she feels some pain, I encourage her to take some Panadol to reduce it. b) I take her history in the book you gave us that looks like a receipt book. It has three papers. The white one, pink and blue. I leave the blue one to confirm that I've worked on her and she can show it to anyone who may happen to have questions. c) I ask if she has any other condition or allergies. Some of them don't know what allergies are but you can explain to them. If they don't have, I go ahead. That's my reply.
Thank you
1a) I first introduce myself to the head of the household and seek their permission to check her or any person in that household.
b) I ask for the number of people in the household and the number of patients.
c) I ask their age

Greetings to my fellow VHTs and thanks for the work you're doing. Greetings to you Catherine as well, thanks for loving us, looking out for us and reminding us what we may have forgotten. This is my reply to the question.
1a) I introduce myself to the patient and ask for her permission to examine her ear. I also take her history.
b) I take the history in the book.

c) I ask for the name of the head of household, their sex and age.  ask how long she has had the condition and whether she received any treatment. If she says no to the latter, I seek for her permission to wash her ears. If she accepts, I wash and dry them and then re examine to see if they're now clean. When I'm done with that, I put three antibiotic drops for three weeks as I do follow up. Regards to you my fellow VHTs and thanks for answering the questions.

Forgive me fellow VHTs, I think my phone is having issues. If I find the 35 year old lady from kirujja butoke, I first introduce myself to her. Question 2) I take her history in a book c) These are the most important questions I ask. I ask for her names, head of household, her condition, how long she has had it and if she had any treatment. First I introduce myself, then I give painkillers for 2 days. After that I washout with iodine, 1ml dissolved in 9mls of clean water. Then I dry mop. After that, antibiotics. 3 drops. I then write things down. The history, names, age, sex, the date, about the patients ears, pus, left vs. right ear. It is good to examine the patient and also for them to get treatment.

Greetings VHTs. About seeing the other 33 year old lady in Kirujja Butoke I saw her and she has a hearing loss in the left ear and it also has pus, even pain, too much pain. The first question - I first ask for permission, then I examine the ear, then I was my hands, then I examine the ear inside and outside. I ask about allergies. If examine and find too much pain and pus I give them pain killers, then after 3 days I get pain killers. Then after washing my hands I examine. Then I write the history. I ask the names of the household head, the age, the date, the sex. After that I fill the remaining parts in the history book. How has the pain been, which ear has the problem. Then I ask about other illnesses. After seeing the outer ear is normal and the ear canal has pus, then after I examine then I write. I give her the form, put one at the health center, I keep one too. I forgot - I also need to get consent too. Part b - I guess I answered that in Part A. I also washout, with iodine and water. I keep washing and dry mopping until there is no pus then I give antibiotics. 3 drops, 3 times a day. 5-7 days.

I have seen today's questions but, I can seen the condition and it's like someone has an inner ear infection. There's a swelling. That patient needs pain killers and after a referral to a bigger hospital.

Good morning. This is the final question for this case. There are no 'right or wrong' answers here. We wish to just see your views and opinions. Q4a. There are long ques and waiting times at Mulago Hospital to be seen by ENT surgeons. Do you think this makes patients avoid going to the hospital even if they need to? What other reasons do people give for not going to a big hospital like Mulago? Q4b. In Uganda in 2009 there were 16 ENT surgeons. In 2015 this number increase to 35, however this number is much lower than a county such as South Africa where there were 246 ENT surgeons in 2015. Why do you think Uganda faces this situation? Q4c. How do you we can we link the limited number of ENT surgeons to the community better so that patients who need surgeons input can be seen and followed up?

4a) The reason as to why people don't go to health centres is not because of long queues but it's because of the few health workers. You see even us when we go out in the community to treat ears, you can work on three people and feel fatigued already. Those health workers get tired, and that's why they're unable to work on some patients. Others ask for bribe. Another issue is, when ears just have discharge some people don't feel pain. In Uganda when someone doesn't feel pain it's hard for them to go to the doctor. That's my point. Also, our government doesn't mind much about health issues. It only cares about security issues. Actually the security budget is higher than that of health. If only the health budget was bigger, we would be so lucky.

Thank you very much Luke, about the idea you have given us. What do you say about the other two questions. I can't see the others? If you need clarification about the question I can do this. We need to get everyone's ideas about the questions.

If the government allocated more money to health, it implies nothing would be impossible. We would be having many health workers including those who treat ears. Seeta Nazigo currently has only two nurses.

There is someone who interrupted me when I was talking, but if the government can help and put money into the health system, things will be possible. They can’t take people to other countries for treatment like China. For example, as you know, most of our doctors who are experts are abroad, meaning they aren't paying them enough money here. Or if not the government doesn't invest in the health sector. We could have ear services if the government cared and gave money to the health center.

This issue, we have to talk about it, so people can understand. If you look at Mukono and Kyunga district they only have 1 ENT doctor. That one doctor has to work on both districts. This means we still have a lot of problems. But our friend 'the owner of the hat' (meaning Musaveni) puts too much money in the military. Even if we don't have people attacking us. I request that at least if we had donors who can fund the health sector that would help us and have ENT specialists who are more than the number that we have. Because we can take an example of South Africa, they have 240 ENT doctors... we need the same. In South Africa people have more power than us. We can do the same as we are many
Hi

Greetings fellow people. My opinion on the first question is, I think money also prevents people from going to mulago. When someone hears about mulago, it implies spending. One wonders where one will get the money from because they don't have it. They know to see a doctor they need money as well as transport especially if they come from very far.
Another issue is, not everyone knows where Mulago is. You always hear elderly people claiming they're from Mulago yet it's not the one. Not knowing where the place is prevents people too.

And the second question, Uganda has that problem because people don't have money to enrol their children in medical courses. It takes a lot of money. They are unable to do it because of the current financial constraints. I think that's why we have few ENT surgeons.

As for the last question, I think we can be able to do that if they reduce on the money needed to educate medical students. If it reduces, the parents can at least find ways of paying for their children. Now if we get 2000 parents in mukono district paying tuition for their children studying to become ENT specialists, the number increases which gets us to another step.

Well done fellows. All you have talked about is right. We go there and find long lines and we don't even get the treatment. The doctors that have studied should be given opportunity to work in health centres. Some doctors are very old and have worked for years me. You go to seek treatment and they refuse to attend to you .Someone feels like they inherited the position and can only leave after death. You hear people have studied but have no jobs but we haven't been helped. I always see from our health centres here for example seeta Nazigo, you find a very old woman tired of giving birth and cannot even advise the pregnant women or take good care of them. I think they should give chance to the fresh ones. That's my opinion.

Thank you all for what you're doing. Those who have answered the questions, thanks for doing so. The first question; 4a) This is my view on what prevents our fellow people from getting to Mulago. The long distances from where we come from is one of them. Late coming on the side of the doctors even when patients are on time and quarrelling as soon as they reach. Pretending even when they arrive early, as if they ain't aware of why they are there. Too many patients waiting in line and some people take the opportunity to make money out of it by asking for something from people in order to get them to the doctors. Lastly, too much money asked from patients found with ear problems.

4b) There's a shortage of doctors which worsens the situation. This is due to low payment for the doctors yet that course is so hard and expensive. Poor payment is generally responsible for the shortage. There's also shortage of equipments even when they have studied it. Another issue is people don't take ear problems seriously and others just don't have interest in studying certain things.  4c) What we can do to ensure such people are taken care of and followed up is  fulfilling the needs of the doctors health wise, personal needs and may be spiritually. Also, training VHTs to acquire more skills than what they already have for example we are now more skilled than our fellow VHTs who were left out. Extending health services nearer to communities for easy accessibility and for VHTs to follow them up easily. That's my opinion.

4c) What we can do to ensure such people are taken care of and followed up is  fulfilling the needs of the doctors health wise, personal needs and may be spiritually. Also, training VHTs to acquire more skills than what they already have for example we are now more skilled than our fellow VHTs who were left out. Extending health services nearer to communities for easy accessibility and for VHTs to follow them up easily. That's my opinion.

Greetings fellow VHTs. My name is Nora and this is my reply to the questions. 4a) The most important issue is lack of transport to facilitate one to and fro, and yet seeing the doctor requires money one may not have at the moment. I think hospitals that treat ears should have various branches for example in Mukono and other areas.

4b) The government hasn't put effort in health issues. For example at seeta nazigo, the doctors are less than the patients but they were able to give us lots of soilders. The government hasn't helped the people at the grassroot in terms of health.

4c) Now us VHTs who have been trained should put in more effort so that we help those who are unable to get to Mulago. If we are fully trained and able to do what is done there, we can always help the people in our communities who are unable to get there. We can easily access them, review their conditions and follow them up.

Now I have a problem. There is a patient I have here. She is 80 yo lady, I gave her ear drops which she has been using. Today is the 5th day. I have washed the ear, but I have seen the wax is near the canal. It is so hard you can see it without putting the otoscope, so even if you put tissue papers they can't go in. I request for one of our helpers to come help me.

4a) Long queues affect patients a lot and sometimes they go back without seeing the doctors. That makes them avoid going to hospitals. Other reasons that prevent them include; - Long distances and transport from Mulago; - Another issue is doctor from government health centers are rude to patients which scares them - Mulago is also expensive. 4b)  Uganda doesn't have enough ENT surgeons because the government gives them little money. Those who have studied are prompted to go abroad thus leading to a shortage. If the government gives them enough money, they will stay in their country.

Fellow VHTs, this is my reply to today's questions. 4a) What prevents patients from going to Mulago is because the president said it's no longer free of charge. They will continue using it to treat only very complicated diseases and someone has to pay some money. The amount I heard him mention was too high to be affordable by common man. Another issue is some people don't know where it's located and the queue is always long. Doctors always want some money which we may refer to as bribe. 4b)In 2009, we had few doctors because all doctors who have gone to school end up going abroad (brain drain). It is an important issue that is caused by low salary. 4c) Those doctors should be coming to health centres grade II, III and IV. They should give out their phone numbers. That's my reply to the questions. I remain Byamukama Gordon.

Greetings fellow VHTs. The first reason as to why patients don't go to Mulago is because the doctors there lack morale. The government cares less about patients. A patient spends the whole day and night in line and still doesn't get seen. It has ever happened to me too. That's the first reason that stops them. Those with money always access them.

Second reason that stops them is government doctors who have so much interest in money and a lot of money. If they don't know who you're or have no attachment to anyone, you cannot access them. The rich get seen first even when you get in line before them. That also discourages people. If there's any way these doctors can change their attitude, we shall be glad.

The problem Uganda has in regards to the other question is it hasn't put effort in health issues. It instead focuses on useless things for example you find the government giving out money to ghettos yet people are dying of cholera. Uganda hasn't focused on important things.

Greetings. I apologise to you - my phone ran out of battery. The power just came today. I got a bit of charge. Let me answer the question right now, even if my fellow VHTs have already answered. Let me also give my idea. What stops people from going to Mulago, my first question is 'Yes, people fail to go there if you don't have any relatives in Mulago or friends or contacts, if you don't have anyone you know you can be there for a week and no one will see you. You need to know someone to get treatment. Another is issue is these doctors - we need to be careful. If you go and they are in a rush they are tough. So even some need money, but the way you approach a doctor. But when you give the money, they receive the money. They look at you with a bad face. They are not compassionate. After that - people give up. It has left people to die.

This problem is there in Uganda (4B), because someone can care about his child and pay for school fees, the child goes to school. After studies the child can't find jobs and those people who are doing those jobs are so old. The parent sees they have lost money on the child. They think of another option - so they tell the child to go abroad to look for jobs. Those people abroad have more opportunities that here in Uganda. That is why they go abroad. So here we don't have experts. Another problem and cause, though our doctors work hard - they get little pay. They know the money is not enough. Even getting that money some of them don't get it on time. They worked for their money, but the administrators take months and months. They stay in self contained rooms which are costly, the need to buy food, pay bills. All this is hard if you don't get paid promptly. These are big sacrifices for them to make. If the conditions are so hard why can't such a doctor just go abroad where they are paid well.

Part C. What we can do. As we have got a chance of being trained as VHTs in the community we can help treat people. We need more training. We can then examine the patients. We should also go house to house looking for people. So it can be easy for the people to approach the doctors if they have a referral letter. So when the patient goes to the health center, they do not look like a new one. So they have a starting point. Another thing the government needs to start paying VHTs as we are trying to save lives. We need help as we need to do this work effectively. The government should add money to the health system instead of funding ministers and members of parliament. They are not doing much. There is another one, the government puts too much money in things thst do not matter. Education and health really matter - the teacher teaches the future doctor, the teacher teaches the future president, but if a teacher doesn't have a good life things for the future won't go so well. Thanks very much.

Thanks you very much. We lost charge as our phones ran out of battery. In Mulago people don't want to see you. You can go there when you are sick but you don't know where to start from . No one in there to guide you. You have to give money at each step of the way. That is why people don't go. Part B. We could have doctors, but they think in our country money has lost value, the money is so little that someone assumes that after going to school they will gain money. But they don't so they go abroad. That is why we don't have enough doctors. Part C. Those doctors should be brought to those small HCs like Mukono because it is near by. Leaving aside the issue of not seeing the doctors, someone from Makata has stayed their whole life here and can't navigate Kampala. This makes them anxious. So I suggest the doctors come closer to the people.
Mr Bryan I am back from the hospital. I just arrived now. I have got some treatment today. They told me to go back on Monday.

Good morning VHTs. How would you manage this patient? What advice would you give them? If wax doesn’t come out after using olive oil and washout what should you do?
After washing the ears of the patient and finding out the wax is still there I do the wash out again, if I found out it is still there after washing out again I refer the patient to the specialist.
The advice I give her is to not insert anything in the ears, like they insert things in their ears then the wax sticks.
Please forgive me - what I have to do for that patient is a wash out, then dry mop, then I check again

Todays question of the patient who had wax yesterday - I apply olive oil drops, 3 drops, 3 times a day, 5 days. Then after the 5 days I wash out with 9mls of H20 and 1 ml of iodine. I then dry mop those ears. If I do all that and the wax remains I put oil in the ears again and then wash out again after 5 days. If it remains again I refer the patient to a specialist. But the advice I give to that patient is not to insert sticks in to their ears - because this can affect the ear canal and ear drum. I also tell them that in case they get problems with their ears they should not self medicate. But they should see a health worker.
Good morning fellow VHTs thank you for your answers. Regards to Madam Catherine thank you for helping us, same regards to Dr. Bryan.

This is my answer to todays question. I give that patient olive oil then I ask them to apply it three drops, three times a day for five days. After the 5 days I go back and do the washout. Then I dry mop.

I advise her not to miss a day of putting the olive oil in. Sometimes you give them the olive oil and they decide not to follow the instructions - they apply it just once a day. But I emphasise the instruction.
Now for the last question. If I see that the wax is still there after doing all that I make a referral to a specialist.

This is what I can do for yesterdays patient. I first explain to her that I am going to give her medicine called olive pil then I give it to them. People see olive oil actually as medicine. I tell her to apply 3 drops, 3 times a day for 5 days.

After the 5 days I ask her to come back to do the washout. Part B. The advice I can give her is to keep applying the olive oil drops and not to insert anything into the ears like sticks. I also tell her not to use any medicine that has not been given to her by ear specialists. Lastly I advise to her come back for follow up to see how she is doing.
Part C. If I do all that and then find out there is still wax I ask her to apply olive oil again for 5 days. Then we do the washout. If it is still there after that then I refer her to a specialist.

Get Wicliffe to review them and if there is an abscess for him to do an incision and drainage.
OK. Thank you I will do this.
Yesterdays question, for the patient who had wax in the ears. If I apply olive oil, I wash out, but the wax still remains. I do it again 2-3 times. If it still fails I refer to specialists.

Greetings fellow VHTs and our bosses. Bryan, Catherine, Hannah. Greetings to you all. Thanks for the questions. I apologise for not replying to the question yesterday. I was so busy. But this is my reply to todays question. For that patient who has wax I explain to them that you have wax and I am going to do a washout and then she will have our medicine of olive oil. I give her the olive oil and show her how to apply it for the first time. Then I tell her to be doing it three times a day for five days. After doing that I ask her to come back to do a washout out. If she has been doing it properly we go ahead and do that washout and dry mopping.

And after doing the dry mopping I check again using my otoscope. If I check and it is not clean yet I mix iodine and water again (1ml of iodine and 9ml of water). Then I wash out. I do it the second time then I check again.

If I check again and I can now see the ear canal I tell her she is now fine. That is how I have answered the first part. Second part. The advise I can give her is to use the olive oil the way she is supposed to. She has to be careful - that is drop by drop and not just pouring it in. Before giving it to her I first show her how to do it. After advising her on how to put it, I tell her not to miss any day. The other advise I can give her is not to insert anything she finds in her ears. Some people use match box sticks or anything they can to insert in their ears. I also advise her to keep her ears clean and to also be careful while showering so water doesn't go inside the ears. That's the advice I give her. Part C. If I apply the oil and do the washout but the wax still remains, I do it again. If I do it again and she still has the wax that means I refer to ENT specialists. I don't insist on continuing as I may damage her ears in the process so I refer to ear specialists. Thank you.
Francesca thank you very much for your reply. But after doing all that and you still find she has the wax what would you do for her?

If I go back and find out the wax is still there. I repeat. I repeat the process of applying olive oil, three drops, three times a day. Then I wash out. If I go back and the wax is still there I refer the patient to an ENT specialist. In a bigger hospital.

After 5 days, I go back and do the washout the advice I can give her is not to insert anything in the ears. And not to use this medicine they hawk and sell in pharmacies. The ones they sell for both ears and eyes. They should only use medicine for health center three and us VHTs.

Good morning fellow VHTs thanks for the work you are doing. Now for yesterdays patient who had wax in the ears. I first introduce myself then I tell her I have brought some medicine called olive oil. She needs to apply it in her ears. Three drops a day for five days.
Thank you Karl you replied the question the way you are supposed to
Thank you Nora your answer is good.

Now the advice I can give to the patient who had wax in their ears is to apply olive oil in the ears. I do it for the first time, I tell her to apply it three drops, three times a day for 5 days. I do the washout after the five days, if I find there is still wax even after doing that, I refer to an ENT specialist.
Dorothy thank you for your reply.
Gordon thanks for your reply but what is the amount of olive oil you put in the ears and how many times do you apply it. Also what advice would you give to the patient?

This is my reply to the question - I have been very busy washing peoples ears. If I washout the patient and the wax still remains I ask him or her to apply the olive oil for two more days, after the two days I do the washout again using iodine and water. If I found the wax is still there after the second wash out and I advise her not to use sticks in the ears. I also advise her to put something in her ears when she is showering so water does not go in her ears. The reason I ask her to do that is to keep her ears clean and dry. That is my reply to the question.

If I apply oil and the wax remains there, I apply it again. Sorry - I do the washout, dry mop, then I check again. If I find the wax is still there, I refer the patient to specialists.

Greetings fellow VHTs I am Isabella Kizza. Sorry for taking long to reply to the question I took a long time to reach home. Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for last week's work. Those with patients and who have lost loved ones may God be with you. I welcome back you all from the meeting at Seeta Nazigo. We thank God for bringing you to attend and I'm sure He has enabled you to reach safely.
This is my reply to today's question. I refer that patient to a specialist, because his condition is hearing loss therefore he needs a hearing aid.

Thank you all fellow VHTs for the work you're doing for the country. Thanks for attending the meeting today. This is my reply to the question. When I see that patient with a hearing loss, I refer him to a specialist and they give him a hearing aid. Have a good day.

Greetings ladies and gentlemen and thanks for the work. I am called Isabella Kizza. I think that patient might have been affected while still young for example    with malaria or yellow fever. When I examine him and I find he has that problem, I refer him to a specialist. Thanks.

Greetings fellow VHTs. This is my reply to today's question of the gentleman called Jamil from Seeta Nazigo, who after examination I discover has no problem with the ears apart from hearing loss. I think he has a problem with the inner part and therefore would refer him to specialists. Specialists say if the inner part is the problem he would need a hearing aid. That's what I would advise as Byamukama Gordon.

Welcome back from the meeting. Thanks for the work. It's me Patricia and this is my reply to today's question. That patient has a hearing loss so I would advise him to go and see ENT specialists for further examination. They would also advise him to get hearing aids to amplify sounds.
I refer that patient to ENT specialists.
This is my reply to that question. When I examine that patient and I find he has that problem, It means the problem is with the inner ear. I therefore refer him to a specialist.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for the work and welcome back from the meeting. Sorry I got there when you had already left. I had some commitments and a burial to attend but I had sent my bag. Concerning today's question, this is my reply. If the patient has a hearing loss but the otoscope shows no problem, I think his problem is to do with the inner ear. I have seen that patient, after seeing them and doing all that I send them to a specialist for further examination. The specialist can see what to do for that one.
Nora, Qiana, Isabella, Gordon, Patricia, Jane, Francesca, Harriet ne Dorothy thanks for taking the time to reply.

Welcome back fellow members, thanks for today's work and that of the weekend. This is reply to today's question. First of all that patient has a hearing loss. What I would do in my capacity is to refer him to an ENT specialist and advising him to get hearing aids. That's what I can do about it.

This is my answer to the question of finding someone with a hearing loss but normal ears. I would refer him to specialists and let him know the charges. I would also tell him hearing aids cost between shs. 800,000 and 1,000,000. His condition is beyond my capacity.

After taking his history, checking his ears and finding no problem but fails the whispered test, it implies his condition is as a result of a middle ear infection. It means the bones of hearing have a problem. I cannot treat this patient but can only let him know he needs referral to a specialist for further examination. The specialist may tell him he needs either surgery or hearing aids. That's what I can do. Thanks.
Your answers are very good - thanks.
He has Hearing loss. You should ideally refer him for assessment by a specialist called an audiologist if you suspect hearing loss.
Good night too and thanks for today.
How has your day been?
Good doctor.
