Good morning VHTs. What are the causes of hearing loss??

Good morning VHTs. Welcome back from yesterday's meeting and thanks for sharing your ideas. Forgive me for not attempting yesterday's question. It's because my phone's battery was dead. As for today's question that is a continuation of that of yesterday, hearing loss is sometimes inborn, sometimes it's as a result of sickness or accidents and many other problems. That's my view and thanks so much for listening to me. Have a good day VHTs. It's me your fellow VHT Johnson Matthew from Makata.

Good morning members. Thanks for yesterday's work and that of today. Today's question requires us to give the causes of hearing loss. Personally, I will give you 4 or 5 causes. First of all, Mr. Jamil is 37 years but has had the problem since childhood which implies he must have suffered from severe malaria leading to that problem. Another cause is some medication like quinine. Formation of a baby in the womb is another one.  There are cases where some body parts are not fully developed and in this particular case it could be the ears. Also, the bone responsible for hearing could be having a hole leading to hearing loss. Fifth cause is Jamil might have been exposed to different sounds like loud places, loud music and welding workshops. That's my opinion.

As for today's question concerning yesterday's gentleman, these are the causes of hearing loss I can give. First of all, diseases can affect ears causing hearing loss. Secondly, loud noises like bullet sounds can cause the problem too. Some people are born with abnormalities on the bones of hearing. Disabilities for example some teachers at schools slap students in the ears. In addition to that, violence in homes causing one partner to beat the other which may damage their ears and cause hearing loss. Using strong medicine like quinine. Lastly, old age though that gentleman is 37 which is not so old. That's my reply to today's question. I remain Gordon, VHT Makata.

This is my reply to the question. Mr. Jamil might been affected as a result of the kind of treatment and care given to people. To be honest, quinine has damaged many people's ears. One uses it without taking enough drinks. Remember these are children and we have to take responsible for their wellbeing. Now, he might have been given quinine by the parents without water. He might also have been sickly as a child and the parents kept giving him quinine tablets. We know quinine tablets cause hearing loss. Secondly, the condition might have started while in the womb. The mother might have been alcoholic, had low immunity or wasn't eating certain nutrients when pregnant which help in the proper formation of the bones of hearing. It might also have been as a result of tough parents who slap their children causing the ear drum to burst. That's what I think. In Seeta there's a 14 year old kid who has a problem with hearing and the mother says quinine is the cause.

First of all, I explain to Jamil that he ain't alone with that kind of problem. It might have been caused by growing up in a home where the children are slapped on the cheeks thus affecting the ears. Another cause could be suffering from malaria and being given quinine as treatment causing damage to the ears. Also, some people are born like that.

Well done fellow VHTs. Sorry if my voice is so low but that's the loudest it can get because I fell sick. I explain to him the causes of hearing loss which include the  following. One can lose hearing while in their mother's womb. In case a pregnant woman falls sick and doesn't get treatment, for example from severe malaria, it affects the baby's brain. Some pregnant women use strong medicine for treatment. Others use alcoholic stuff, drugs like marijuana which affects the baby's brain causing hearing loss. Some people use head sets with loud sound which leads to bursting of the ear drum. Accidents also cause hearing loss for instance when one falls and the ears are affected. May be diseases from old age too and the treatment given thereafter like quinine. That's my reply.

Greetings fellows and  this is my reply to the question. Factors that may cause hearing loss include the following. Some medication like quinine given to people with severe malaria. It is well known that quinine causes hearing loss. Secondly, some people are born like that. The ones referred to as deaf. Another issue may be a perforation because  Dr. Esther told us sometimes there are times when certain parts of the skin fail to come together to form a normal ear or the bones of hearing might have an abnormality. Another cause is one may have got an accident and not realize how bad it was. Others are exposed to loud sounds like those who work in factories, where as others use headsets with loud music yet their hearing may not have been good resulting into profound hearing loss.

Thanks for the work fellow VHTs. It's me Qiana and this is my reply to today's question. He might have been born with a hearing loss. Another cause could be use of some medication like quinine in a strong dose. Thirdly, he could have been slapped in the ears causing hearing loss. Thanks.

Greetings fellow health workers. Thanks for treating people and I love you all in Jesus Christ. I also thank Catherine and Bryan for the work they're doing. I thank Andrew for loving us. May God bless you all. This is my reply to today's question. Yesterday, we confirmed Jamil has a hearing loss. I think his mother could have fallen sick or got very stressed while pregnant. Some homes are violent and full of fights and when a pregnant woman goes through that, it affects the baby's brain. That man could also have fallen sick while still young and the parents didn't notice in time which worsened the ears. He might also have grown up around a place with loud sounds for example a stone quarry, bars, lodges or cinemas. His parents may have also communicated with him in a manner where they kept shouting. Other causes include;- Formation of his bones of hearing could be abnormal.-Medications we use and not just quinine but others too. -Use of certain things. One may have a minor problem but is advised to use lots of things which cause complications hence bringing infections.

Greetings fellow VHTs - thanks for yesterdays work and welcome back from the meeting. Forgive me for taking long to reply but my phone is having issues. I explain the patient that the cause of their hearing loss may be due to maternal factors during pregnancy, like taking alcohol, using herbs. Another reason could be ototoxic medicines, that could have cause the hearing loss.

Greetings fellow VHT and thanks for the work you are doing. I explain to the patient their hearing loss could be from flu or cough, and their parents were reluctant to take them to the hospital. Some of us look at those disease like they are simple but as a child they may effect you alot. He could have been taken to a clinic with doctors who are not well trained and given wrong medicines which cause hearing loss. Can also tell her that maybe some patients used herbs which worsened the condition and may have damaged the inner ear.

Since the person got the condition aged 5, it means he had hearing before that. I think an acquired cause of hearing loss could be exposure to loud sounds, overdosing on certain ototoxic medicines, or he might have had trauma to the ear. I then tell them in case they had seen ear specialists earlier on he may not have developed that condition.
I explain to that patient that they might have gotten malaria and they were given quinine causing the problem.

Greetings fellow VHTs, this is my reply to the question. Some of the causes of hearing loss include, use of quinine when someone is sick, some are naturally born with damage to their ears, that is what I have to say.

Thank you the causes of hearing loss are: Medications (e.g. certain antibiotics cause hearing loss if the dose is too high like gentamycin), loud noises, old age (prebycusis), infections (measles and mumps) are some of the causes of hearing loss.
Good morning VHTs. This is todays question. You explain to him the causes of hearing loss. He asks you what treatment is available. What do you tell him?

Greetings VHTs and thanks for the work. After explaining to Jamil the causes of hearing loss  and he asks the kind of treatment he needs, I would tell him he needs surgery by an ENT surgeon or hearing aids. I would also tell him before all that, it must have been confirmed by an audiologist. That's my reply for today's question. Thanks so much.

This is my reply to today's question. After seeing Mr. Jamil and confirming his ears have no other problem besides hearing loss, I explain to him what could be used to help him. I let him know about hearing aids and their cost which is between shs. 800,000 and shs.1,000,000. I also direct him to ENT specialists who sell them instead of just buying from anywhere like someone purchasing groundnuts or a phone. And that the ENT specialist must confirm it first.
I explain to him that the treatment he can have may consist of surgery or hearing aids, but that can only be determined by a specialist. I direct him to that specialist.

After explaining the causes of hearing loss to Mr. Jamil, and he asks the treatment he needs, I would tell him he has to be seen by an ENT specialist for further examination. It is then determined whether he needs surgery or hearing aids but this is only done by an ENT specialist for example Dr. Tamale at Naggalama or Mulago. And may be our doctors from Mbarara. After explaining that to him, I advise him not to let himself get confused by people suggesting he uses herbal medicine. You know some people are fond of misleading others. He can only see medical doctors like the ones I've mentioned.

Good morning fellow VHTs. Thanks for yesterday's work and we thank God for keeping us alive till now. Now, this is my reply to today's question. After explaining to him the causes of hearing loss, I let him know that he needs a specialist for treatment because his condition is beyond our capacity. They may get him hearing aids or something else.
Greetings VHTs and thanks for the work. I also tell Jamil that he may need surgery or hearing aids according to what the ENT specialist decides. I also encourage him not to lose hope.

The treatment or what I can do for Mr. Jamil after explaining to him the causes of hearing loss is to go and learn sign language. I also refer him to a specialist to continue helping him because his condition is beyond me. That's my advice.

Thank you Karl, Luke, Dorothy, Gordon, Nora ne Isabella. All of your answers to the question are correct. After everyone has answered and it is 8pm I will give the answer and the procedures to follow .
Thank you Jane

Well done fellow VHTs. The advise I would give to Mr. Jamil is to go to Mengo hospital because they also specialise in treating people ears. If he's unable to go there, he could then go to an ENT specialist. I would emphasize he shouldn't put herbal medicine which may end up worsening his condition. He can also go to bigger hospitals where they can do surgery or give him hearing aids. On that note, I would remind him to go with some money because the hearing aids are costly.

Thanks for all the work you've done today fellows. I would tell Mr. Jamil that his condition of hearing loss needs examination by ENT specialists or hearing aids to amplify sounds. That's what I can do.

Greetings fellow VHTs and thanks for the work you're doing for the country. This is my reply to the question. After explaining to the patient that I cannot handle him, I refer him to ENT surgeons for re-examination. From that examination they can determine whether to carry out surgery on his ears or give him hearing aids.
Patricia, Edward ne Harriet thankyou very much for your responses.

The VHT should explain to him that to confirm the hearing loss they would need to refer him to a specialist called an audiologist who can test his hearing using special tests. Unfortunately however, there are not many audiologists in Uganda. The ones that are there are expensive and only in Kampala. There are some treatments for hearing loss like hearing aids and cochlear implants but these are also expensive. A hearing aid costs 6 million shillings for one, and the batteries need changing each week. Each battery costs 20,000 shillings. There are other things that the VHT can recommend. For young children with hearing loss they can go to special schools for the deaf for example. Here they can learn sign language and communicate. They can also give advice such as wearing ear protection to prevent hearing loss in the first place if they are exposed to loud noises in their job, or avoiding medicines which can cause hearing loss. The VHT can also explain to family members how to communicate with someone who struggles to hear properly. For example, speaking slowly, clearly and loudly. Not covering the mouth with the hand when talking to someone. Pointing to objects they are referring to. Being patient.If a baby has two parents who are deaf they should spend time with family members who are not deaf as this can otherwise affect their language development. Remember people who are deaf have normal intelligence.

Thanks VHTs for the work you are doing for the country. After explaining to that gentleman his condition and then he asks for the treatment needed, I ask him to go to bigger hospital like Mulago where there are specialists. Those specialists can examine him again for hearing. I also explain to him those are the people who will give him treatment. I call those people ENT specialists. They can give him hearing aids or carry out surgery. That is the advice I can give him because at that point his condition is beyond me. Thank you so much.

Good morning VHTs. Q4A. Have you met a lot of people in the community with hearing loss? What do you think are the main causes of hearing loss in Mukono? Q4B. Do community members get frustrated that there are no resources for treatment such as hearing aids? Q4C. How can you as VHTs improve the situation for the those with hearing loss if there are not many audiologists and hearing aids are expensive?

I will begin with the last question then answer the rest afterwards. Greetings to you all. If ENT specialists say that hearing aids are expensive, what I would do as a VHT is to counsel them. I would also politely advise them to go to schools that teach sign language. From there they can a lot of things. I know those people can even be more intelligent than us who are able to hear and speak properly.

Question A. Yes, I meet a lot of deaf people in my community. The causes of hearing loss in Mukono include the following. Different kinds of treatment that happen to be bad especially for us the poor people at the grass root. You can get to the health centre and find no medication yet you have a very sick child with malaria and convulsions. You then seek advise from different people who tell you to buy quinine claiming it cured their sick children. One ends up giving those tablets to their children but forget to give them lots of water. I know quinine ain't bad but it becomes a problem when a parent fails to give water to the sick child all the time so it can dissolve it. The child ends up losing her hearing in the process. I call upon the government to bring back the waterly quinine because it's good for the children and doesn't cause hearing loss like the tablets. We were trained on how to self Medicate in Mukono, due to the situation at the health centre of inadequate medicine. Coartem is so expensive in clinics   yet quinine is cheaper. At shs. 500 you can get yourself two tablets but for coartem the first dose is at shs. 5000

In case people fail to go to the health centre because the treatment for ears ain't there or it's expensive yet they have no money, I counsel them and advise them to go and learn sign language. After that they will be fine and able to communicate with others. I can also look for those schools and direct them. They cannot feel sorry for themselves after that.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for yesterday's work. Good morning Miss Catherine, Mr. Bryan and the VHTs. Thanks for answering yesterday's question and the rest of the work you're doing. Question A. Yes, we meet so many deaf people. Just like the gentleman we talked about, there are so many causes of hearing loss for example sickness, use of strong medicine, accidents, getting beaten and poor treatment. Some people apply herbal medicine to their ears. Others ignore infections thinking they will cure by themselves. That's how I've answered the first question. It's me VHT Johnson Matthew.

Question B. People get frustrated. First of all, they are poor and the government doesn't care so much about people at the grass root. You get to the health centre, for example I've personally moved to several government health facilities and haven't been helped at all. It discourages people and they decide to stay home whether their hearing is good or not. One ends up having so much on one's mind for instance poverty, business ain't operating smoothly, government health centres are not helping at all, imagine people like us! Where can one get the shs 3,000,000? You can't even raise it even if you decided to sell a plot of land. It frustrates us and we end up developing other diseases. That's my reply to the second part of the question.

Question C. In case specialists come and I have people with hearing loss in my community, as a VHT I would come together with my fellows and ensure we counsel them. We can come up with a health camp like the one we had at seeta Nazigo health centre III and bring them together. Others may be having their relatives with jobs and money so they can be helped. That's my only suggestion. Counselling them because we don't have money to give them neither are we ENT specialists. Only thing we can do is advising them and counselling them whenever that camp is conducted. Those who can access help, well and good but those who are not able to can be helped that way. That's my reply to the third question. It's me VHT Johnson Matthew. Have a good day our health workers who are present and the rest of the VHTs.

As VHT Gordon, this is my reply to today's question. The biggest cause of hearing loss amongst people in Mukono are the machines used in stone quarrying. They are so loud and it's a big problem because we have so many of them in Mukono. They   burst people's ears causing hearing loss.

Question B. People are discouraged when there's no treatment for hearing loss. Hearing aids are so expensive yet the disease is so rampant amongst the poor. People are unable to purchase them which is a big problem. I heard that they cost between shs. 700,000 and shs. 3,000,000. Some of our patients here in Makata were once told the same thing.

As VHTs, what we can do for those people is to ask the government to cooperate with developed countries in order to reduce the price of hearing aids. That's all we can do as VHTs including me Gordon. Have a good day, I remain Gordon.

Some of the causes of hearing loss amongst people in Mukono include; sickness, self medication, illness, neglecting ear problems, herbal medicines, some are born like that, wrong medicines, loud noises. Part B: People don't know where to go or are too poor to afford to see a doctor. Part C: As a VHT I can continue to sensitise them on not neglecting diseases; avoiding things that might be harmful to the ears; how to take good care of the ear.

I greet you all fellow members and thanks for the work. Today's question has 3 parts. Question A. These are my opinions on the causes of hearing loss in Mukono. So many factories especially loud ones lead to producing of children with hearing loss. So many stone quarries that are loud as well also cause hearing loss. Medication given in health centres. Parents neglecting sick children when the diseases are still in their early stages like malaria, measles also causes hearing loss.B. Yes, people get frustrated. Treatment for hearing loss is very expensive especially hearing aids. Besides being expensive, people are not aware of where to find them. They may end up buying fake ones after spending a lot of money on them. They are not even sure of the amount of money they cost. In addition to that, they also need special care like phones. One may be unable to afford batteries. The machines used to test hearing loss are so rare. You will get to the health centre and not find them yet the distance travelled to get there might have been long. Poverty amongst people really discourages them.C. As a VHT, what I can do is to advise pregnant women to get maternal services right from when they find out they are pregnant till when they give birth. They should also take good care of their babies and not to neglect any disease. They should also spend less time in loud places like the factories we talked about and discotheques which may affect their ears. Lastly is to request the government to put restrictions on loud places so that they can reduce on the sound they produce. If such restrictions are put in place, our people won't be so much affected. Those are my opinions.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Sorry I was unable to answer yesterday's question because my phone battery was dead. This is my reply to the causes of hearing loss amongst people in Mukono. Most of the time people get ear infections with no where to go for treatment so they resort to using herbal medicine. Someone spends 30 years with no treatment because they have no idea where to find the ENT specialists. B. Yes, people get discouraged because they haven't received any treatment and have no money to buy hearing aids. C. What I can do for such people is to counsel them and let them know they ain't alone.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Apologies for taking long to reply to the question. Thanks for yesterday's work. Miss Catherine and Bryan, I send my regards to you. Thanks for serving and loving us. This is my reply to today's question. The biggest cause of hearing loss amongst people in Mukono is sickness like severe malaria especially amongst children. You decide to go to the health centre, line up till 3pm and by the time they get to you the child is worse. They give you quinine tablets to give to them but you're too poor to afford drinks so in the process, the child ends up losing their hearing.

B. People are frustrated because of poverty. It all goes back to poverty. People are asked to buy the hearing aids but they give up because they don't have money. If only the government puts more emphasis on health issues for example by constructing more facilities where people can buy hearing aids, they may cost way cheaper than they do now. It hasn't put any effort in health but has instead done so in security.

C. For such people, I can only counsel them because it's all I can do. All of us VHTs cannot do much about that. You can ask them if they have their people who can help them and if they say no, you go ahead and counsel them so they don't feel stressed. My regards to you all fellow VHTs. I remain Nora, seeta Nazigo.

B.As VHTs, we should keep teaching people how to take good care of their ears because hearing aids are expensive and learning sign language requires money too. They should therefore take care of their ears and see doctors as soon as they discover they  have any problem with them.

C. As VHTs, it's our responsibility to explain to and sensitise people on how to take good care of their ears. It's important not to give up until we are sure they know and understand what to do. We should also sensitize them on some of the myths in communities like buzzing sounds that are mistaken for someone being talked about, itching that implies one has syphilis and others. Since our doctor has discovered many issues of hearing loss, he probably has something he can do about it. Hearing aids are expensive but he can find a way to help. When he goes back, he can find ways or else in Uganda we are likely to have many deaf people. May be government health centres should also sensitize people on the diseases they treat including ears.

Greetings to you all my fellow VHTs. Sorry for taking long but my phone had got issues. The question requires us to give the causes of hearing loss amongst people in Mukono. In 1983, there was an outbreak of measles amongst children. They were given strong medication which might have caused hearing loss. Self medication also causes hearing loss and using sticks when ears itch. Some may be born that way. In Mukono, we have stone quarrys that also cause hearing loss.
B. People are frustrated because they don't know where  to go. Poverty also discourages them and may be ignorant.
As a VHT, what I can do is to sensitize them on what to do and ask them to avoid things that may affect their ears.

Greetings to you all and this is my reply to the question.A. The biggest cause of hearing loss in Mukono district is sickness which affects their bodies. Medication causes the problem too. Inserting sticks in their ears to remove wax and stone quarries also cause hearing loss. B. Yes, people are discouraged when there are no hearing aids or if they're unable to afford them. C. As VHTs, what we can do is to advise people on how to prevent ear problems that can cause hearing loss. I also call upon the government to offer free treatment for people with hearing loss or to reduce on the tax of hearing aids during their importation to Uganda so they are affordable. They should also deploy more ENT specialists in government health centres. That's my reply to today's questions. Thanks so much.
Thanks very much Edward for those views because they are vey good. Continue encouraging pregnant women to go to the health centre like you said.
Thank you very much Francesca for that reply. If you find people in the community with hearing loss and can not afford hearing aids please take your time to encourage them.
Thank you Nora for that. Please continue counselling people with hearing loss in case you find them.
Thank you Dorothy, you have given a very good opinion and please continue to encourage people and sensitise them on how to prevent hearing loss.
Thank you very much Jane, please continue sensitising people on how to take care of their ears.
Isabella thank you so much for what you have said and please continue to sensitise people
Thank you so much Karl. You have given a very good point and keep sensitising people to keep their ears clean.

I greet you all fellow VHTs. Thanks for today's work, everything you're doing and for answering the questions. This is my reply as well to today's questions. A. What causes hearing loss in Mukono is chaos. People are always rioting, bullets are being shot, so much noise, factories are many, stone quarries all of which cause hearing loss. Another issue is people's mindset of being bewitched all the time. It makes them think they will never get fine. A baby is born with a hearing loss, but the parents don't mind about it and thereafter claim someone bewitched them when pregnant or their child. Thirdly, sometimes when we give birth to babies we don't take responsibility to check their hearing yet if we do it earlier the problem can easily be detected.

B. Yes, it frustrates people. First of all hearing aids are very expensive, and only a few people are aware of them besides us who got a chance to be trained. Honestly speaking I've only come across one person with them in my whole village. Unfortunately they got stolen. Out of ignorance, one decides to give up after all they may not be having the money. Secondly, the batteries are expensive. For someone to spend shs.20,000 yet eats food without sauce and cannot afford soap may not be possible.

C. What I can do for deaf people as a VHT include the following. First of all those people need to be shown love. Someone like me who is able to hear needs to do the few signs I know happily, show them that I care and love them and that I am not special because they need company. I can also teach these people things they do not know like how to keep their ears clean and free from infections much as they are deaf. I also teach them spiritual things. God created people and all is possible before Him. He used to heal the blind, deaf and lame people. I can therefore advise them to go and see pastors who are not fake. There are those who have believed with faith and got their hearing back after prayers. That's how I've answered those questions. May God bless you. Thanks Catherine, Bryan, Andrew and my fellow VHTs.
Thank you very much Harriet for your opinion. In case you find anyone with hearing loss please help them the way you told us.

VHTs we are very grateful for all your replies this week. All of you have given very good views. Please continue to share ideas and help people with hearing loss in your communities in the ways you have mentioned. We are done with the questions for this week. Have a good night.

Question 2. In case I find those people in my community, I counsel them and tell them they are not alone. I also tell them there are organisations which bring together the deaf people. I advise them that there are organisations that empower deaf people with technical skills in carpentry and tailoring using sign language. We have encountered such people in society and they are usually very good. That is the advise I can give there are also schools that can teach deaf people using sign language.

Thanks all VHTs for today work thanks for replying to todays case. Thanks you for Catherine and Bryan for the work you are doing for us. The one greeting you is Qiana Kigwana. This is how I reply my first question. In Mukono the reason why we have people with hearing problems is because some parents when they get pregnant they don't want to go to hospitals for check up - then the kids get ill. Some used to go to private shops and buy quinine and swallow - yet malaria is too much. So after taking the quinine they take too much of it so by the moment that they produce that child they come out with a hearing issue. Another thing someone can produce a child who hears very well, but sometimes the child gets sick but gets too much malaria then they get treatment with quinine then the quinine becomes too much because my inlaws child has this issue. They always advise them to use quinine which is why the child does not hear, yet the child was good but these days we use sign language. Now he is in S1, but he was produced when he was normal but the problem was quinine. Quinine was the medicine every just took without even knowing if it was the right one. Even pregnant women. But because when pregnant women go to hospitals they get a different drug.

My third question - after seeing that the equipment is expensive I encourage them and advise them that there are technical schools, where they can go and learn. Because even the teachers who teach them use sign language. So that way they can develop themselves instead of staying the same when they don't know anything. Yet in those technical schools some do craft work, weaving baskets. They also teach them as people who hear. They also have a chance and an opportunity because those people train in construction, carpentry sand many more. They can be trained in sign language - a bit like the blind with braille. Because the blind can't see but they have special equipment. So the same applies to the deaf. There are many things they can use to help them. Though they can't hear they can see what can be done. So they can see each sign they are taught.
Thank you very much Qiana

Greetings members. I have an issue. I have two children. The mother told me in the first 3 months the child had pus in the ear - they treated it, it got normal. Then 6 months later it came back. But right now the child is 4 years and the pus has come back. Right now the child does not have pus - but if you stand at the back of the child the child does not hear. So instead you have to stand in front of the child otherwise the child will not hear you. But behind they do not hear. So I need help about this child. I also have another one who is the elder of this one - 6 years old. They are girls. They also told me they have a similar problem - they used to have pus, the mum put warm water and would drain it from the ear which means the child never got antibiotics.  I examined and didn't see any pus but wax and itching. So I need your advice what can I do? Bryan and Catherine I need your advice as I fill the forms - because if they need antibiotics I don't have them right now. But I will do what is possible and let you know. Thank you so much.

Edward what I think. The first thing you can do, get your camera and take photos of the child, then send it to us for both kids. The second one, you have to wash her ear out, remove the wax, but what is best is to take photos of both kids and send them to us. Remember though don't get their faces in it - just the ears for the reasons of consent.

Another thing; remind them in May that there will be an ear camp at Seeta Nazigo. The doctors are coming - ENT. Also I think let the patients give you their phone number, the mum. Then you call her once we know the date.
The ear canal is painful and full of pus
What is the solution to the pinna?
As you can't do the ear wash out due to the pain, refer her to health center to get the pain killer and then give Antibiotics for a week. Apply 3 drops by 3 times a day.

Morning members, I need your help on this issue, I have a client here, he says he has pain in the left ear, but when we looked in the ear, the ear drum is normal, but when you look in the right ear which doesn't pain him, there is too much wax, what can I do for this patient, I new your advice now and at least I do something before the patient goes.
Thank you Edward, what I can say, the ear with wax needs olive oil and that with pain I think the person needs pain killers and we see how he will be. That is my idea.

Mr Edward, I have understood your case, but my suggestion is not so different from that of Dorothy, or you can refer the patient to the Health Centre to give him some medicine to reduce on the pain. That's my view.
Greetings Edward, thanks for the work you are doing.
Greetings Edward, me too my idea is not so different from my fellow friend's views, give him olive oil on the er with wax and then some pain killers for pain. Thank you for your work.
Mr Edward me too, my view is the same as that of Dorothy, olive oil and pain killers, if the pain doesn't stop then we can ask our in-charges  about what to do.

The need to be treated with cleaning the ear, then giving pain killers, antibiotic drops 3 times a day for at least 7-10 days. The may also need amoxicillin if they have upper respiratory tract infection. If the infection doesn't heal with antibiotic ear drops they may need something stronger - like oral flucloxacillin
Agree with you Dorothy. Edward, give him olive oil to soften the wax for at least 5 days (need to apply the olive oil 2-3 times a day for at least 5-7 days). Then wash out

Hello VHTs. Thank you for all of your hard work. This case is designed around the feedback you have been providing us. It concerns itching ears. You go to see a patient in Makata called Annette who is 50 years old. She is complaining of both ears itching. You take a history and examine her. She has been bothered by itching in her ears for the last 5 months. She has no pus and no wax in her ears. When you look inside the ear with your otoscope it looks normal.  Q1. What do you think the causes of ear itching could be?

As Luke this is my reply to the question. After examining Annette and taking her history, and realising that her only problem is itching but the inside is normal, I honestly don't know what to do. I don't know what causes the itching since there's neither wax nor pus. I would like you to tell me and I have always been asking the cause. So, I don't know.

I have seen today's question of a lady called Annette who has a problem of ears itching for 5months. I think the cause is this person might have used sticks to clean her ears. These sticks can affect the ear canal. Also, the skin of the ear canal might be having an infection. That infection may cause the itching. I would also say wax but after examining it shows there's no wax so I think it's one of those two. Either she used sticks in her ears or the skin of her ear canal has an infection. Thank you.
It's me Jane. I think the problem is in the inner ear and I refer her to specialists.

Good morning my brothers and sisters. Thanks for the work you're doing. We thank God for the rain today. Greetings Catherine and Bryan. How are you Andrew? How's everything? Thank God who has kept you while there. I have seen today's question and this is my reply. If I examine and find no problem like wax, pus or even a hole, it means the skin has an infection. Another reason is some people have allergies and may not be aware. Ears react faster than any other body part. That's my reply. It's either allergy or a skin infection. Rubbing them to ease the itching is also another one. The more someone does it, the more it itches. Thank you.

Greetings fellow VHTs everywhere in our villages. I am Isabella Kizza. When I check the 50 year old lady called Annette and find no problem besides itching for 5 months, I first advise her not to use sticks to ease the itching. I can also refer her to specialists. That's my reply
Ok Luke let others also give their views then we shall give you the causes of itching in the ear.
Karl thanks so much for your answer
Jane we want to know what causes itching in the ear before we know what to do with the patient.
Thank you Harriet
Other VHTs what do you think causes itching in the ear?

Greetings fellow VHTs. How was your night? This is what I have to say. When I go to Makata and find a 50 year old lady called Annette with itching in the ears, and I take her history but on examining I find nothing like pus or wax in her ears, what I have to say doesn't differ from what others have already said or will say. I have three reasons. First of all, Annette is now old and her age is prone to diseases. Secondly, she might be having germs in her body. Thirdly, she might be using some medicine she is allergic to. I think those reasons could be causing itching in Annette's ears. May be another reason is she could be having wounds that we are unable to see. By the time she inserts sticks, it means the finger is too short to reach the inside. There could be wounds that are still not so visible. It's just like a swelling that itches but only becomes a wound after it bursts. That's my opinion.
Thanks Isabella. But before that, what do you tell the patient what causes itching in the ear?
Ok Edward, thanks.

Greetings VHTs. This is my reply to that question. When I look inside the ear and see no pus or wax but the lady experiences itching, there could be germs. May be she had a shower and water went in her ears  and now there are germs. Her condition needs specialists.

Now, given Annette's condition the 50 year old lady from Makata, this is what I think could be the cause of her ears itching. Some people have skin diseases but because they don't feel pain, they don't bother treating them. Sometimes you find a child or adult with ringworms in the head, another with dandruff yet another may not be having any. She may be having a skin disease in the hair that may be affecting the ears when she tries to scratch it. Secondly, she may have used something that shouldn't be used in the ears like sticks, dirty water, medicine and others. I think that's what causes ears to itch.
As Qiana this is what I do for an ear with wax. I apply olive oil 3drops, 3times a day for 5 days. After that I washout.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Bryan and Catherine, I was over there but you weren't around. Greetings our in charge Mr Andrew wherever you are. I got a patient who I sent to you, he went to some health centre but after discussing with Byamukama, we decided to refer him to you. Unfortunately, he didn't find any of you there. As for Annette's case, I don't differ from Edward. As we get old our bodies change. Medicines we use can also have effects at times. It needs specialists. Good night fellow VHTs. I remain Matthew.
Ok Francesca, thank you.
Qiana, you have not replied to the question correctly. So you observe again very well, but thanks for your time.
Thank you Dorothy for your answer
Thank you very much Mr. Matthew

Thank you very much for those who have taken the time to reply to todays question. You have given good ideas about what causes itching in the ear, but among the causes of itching in the ear are…. Have a good night lets wait for tomorrows case.
You explain to her that the inside of the ear looks normal. She asks you for treatment. She insists you give her antibiotic ear drops. What do you tell her?  What treatment do you give her?

Good morning VHTs. I greet you all in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ. As Luke, I let Annette know that I won't give her antibiotics because they could damage her ears. I advise her to keep them clean and to also get checked for any skin infections. That's how I explain to her. May be the issue of age too but we were told it's usually 60years and above not 50. I ensure she's satisfied with my explanation about the antibiotic drops being dangerous to her ears that seem normal before I leave her home. All white medicines have effects including Panadol which may damage your liver if taken in over dose. On that note I ask her to be patient and visit the health centre for examination of any skin infections. Thank you so much.

Greetings fellow VHTs. I would like to thank you for all the work you're doing and for replying to the questions. Regards to you madam Catherine. I have been lost because my phone got a problem so my messages were not getting delivered and I couldn't receive yours either. I also had my tooth removed in the last week of March which caused a swelling and so much pain. I got a specialist who repaired my phone and now I am back online. This is my reply to yesterday's question but please forgive me for the delay. I cannot do anything for the patient but rather refer her to specialists for help.

Now for today's question of Annette asking for treatment for her itching ears, I personally refer her to the health centre to get pain killers. They can also examine her and if they have no medicine for her problem, they can write it down for her to get it from any pharmacy. If she insists on getting antibiotics I explain to her that I examined her ears and there's nothing like pus or perforations. Such ears don't need antibiotics and if we apply them she may get some side effects because it would be the wrong medication. I strengthen her and advise her to go to the health centre for medicine that can stop that itching. In case they don't have it, she can get it from the pharmacy after them writing it down. That's my answer to today's question. Thank you so much.

I also greet you VHTs; so for todays question what I do for Mrs. Annette I don’t give antibiotics even if they want them so much. I don’t give them and explain why I am not giving them antibiotics. I explain to her I examine the ears when they are normal so she does not need to use the antibiotics. I also don't see any kind of treatment that needs to be given to her as she only has itching in the ear. Itching in the ear does not have medicine. But what I can tell her, is that it could be because of too much heat, wax and bacteria like fungus. So I tell her to go to the hospital for more examination. That is where she can get treatment from.

Good morning members. Thanks for the work we have started doing today. That lady Annette, we discovered yesterday she has itching in the ear, so we were told that sometimes itching comes because of some bacteria in the body. But in all situations there is no way that antibiotics are recommended for this. So if they are so hard on me and want antibiotics I refer them to the specialist. Then the specialist will assist them to reduce pain from itching. Then also to get some tablets for deworming for kids. They might have worms in the body. Another thing I can do, not to make her angry I just ignore her and refer her to the people who know more than me. Then I inform her - let those people examine you but if they find a problem in you I will see if you can get medicine but right now I don't have the medicine for you.

Greetings all of you. My name is Gordon. So when I approach this lady called Annette from Makata who wants antibiotics for itching in the ear, when the ears have no problem, just itching. So I don’t give antibiotics to that lady. I tell her antibiotics do not work for itching I make a referral for her to go to another hospital so they can examine and tell her what the issue is. Because yesterday I saw that itching might be because of itching, too much heat in the ear canal and too much wax like we saw yesterday so there is nothing I can give her. I refer her to a big hospital because I don't have any treatment for itching. That is my view. I am Gordon.

Greetings my fellow VHTs,  sorry Hadjjah but god cares. That lady Annette, after examining her knowing she does not have any problem, but she insists to be given the antibiotics, I explain to her you do not need the antibiotics because first of all, there is no wound, no pus. I inform some of the causes of itching might be trying to scratch your ear using sharp objects, the more you itch it with something it creates more itching. But if I refer her to the specialists to examine her she might be having the other bacterias we saw yesterday. Those which affect the ear, maybe some allergies. Thanks so much.

Greetings VHTs. Thanks for todays work and also replying to the questions. The reason you have not been hearing me - my charger got an issue, so I did not have anywhere to charge from. That is why you did not hear from me. For todays case, this is how I reply. What I advise Mrs. Annette. I don't give her antibiotics, antibiotics are only given to people with pus in the ear and perfs. But those who have itching aren't given antibiotics. I also advise her to keep her ears clean, if it has wax, use olive oil. So that we can soften the wax and washout. But if the itching goes on I refer the lady to the hospital.

Greetings VHTs, thanks for the work you are doing and for those who have replied to the questions thank you. My answers are not also different from the others. About that lady called Annette from Makata, about her problem of itching, the truth is that some patients want to pretend they know more than us so they force you to do things that can harm themselves. According to me - if she has asked me to do that and when I examine there is not indication for antibiotics, I don't give her them. Because if you put the medicine in the body it becomes poison if there is no need for it. So I cant give someone something which is going to cause harm. So I tell her the truth - this medicine can't be given to you, so I refer her to the specialists to understand what causes the itching.

Greetings VHTs - thanks for the work. That lady Annette, if she insists for me to give her antibiotics, I tell her that the antibiotics will cause you problems. This illness is not for antibiotics. But if you had discharge from the ear like pus then you can use antibiotics. So what I advise her, I tell her to go to the hospital. I tell her to go to SN HCIII. They can examine her and give her treatment as I don't have any for itching.
That lady Annette, when I examine her ear and doesn't have pus or a hole but itching I tell her not to use sticks to clean her ears.

Well done VHTs; I am sorry I am having network issues with my phone. I sent my reply but it delays to send. I am sorry. For todays case my answer is this - that lady Annette when I examine it and it has no wax, pus, hole but has itching I tell her that there might be fungus making the ear itch. In the field some people call you, you examine them but just have itching. Others have wax, but with itching in the ear. And others have normal ear drums but itching in the ear. I also remember we talked about this issue and we said people are always asking you for treatment. So for us we say Bryan, Catherine and Dr, Andrew give us the right answer and give us the medicine that can heal the itching in the ear. There is a man I know - his ear has things like dust which also brings itching in the ear. Even if they use sticks to clean their ears. But they can't use the sticks if the ears are not itching. Which means they have an issue with their ears. Even me I am also one of them. Before I was washed out it also used to itch me sometimes - that is why someone can try to insert something in the ear which can damage it. So we don't have a perfect answer; I just refer them to the specialist so they can be assessed properly. That is my view - have a good night. I have an issue with the network

Thank you very much Luke, Nora, Karl, Dorothy, Edward, Gordon, Patricia, Harriet, Qiana, for you replies I apologise for not replying to each of you but today I was so busy. All the same I heard all your replies. Some of you say your itching has no medicine, others say refer the patient. Those two are not correct, but I will give you the correct reply at 8pm. I haven't heard from Matthew and Jane - hope they are ok?

I would like to thank my fellow VHTs reply to the question yesterday. I have seen todays question of the 50 year old woman who has a problem with itching but the ears are normal inside. Here yesterday we said some of the causes are old age, not cleaning it enough. Since the lady has no wax, I will give her olive oil. They say she needs to apply it two or three times a day. For 3-5 days. After that she goes back to the VHT for a washout. The itching is caused my so many things, infections, heat. Ok that is what I have to say. You apply oil. She might have used sticks. Thanks very much.
I have not been around and had no battery
I am asking for forgiveness
Haha Ok. No problem
Matthew thanks for that reply.

The correct reply to the question is as follows. If the patient asks for Abx drops you explain it is not necessary and you don't give it to them. You give them olive oil drops or the steroid drops in case itching is too much and the skin of the ear canal is red. You explain that the steroid drops can make the skin red. Then you tell them that they should not use sticks, cotton, or anything else to rub the ears. You explain to them why, the reason why it may affect the ear canal or damage it. Goodnight and lets wait for tomorrows question.
Thanks for the work VHTs and the replies. Thanks for the replies to the questions.

After advising her to purchase steroid ear drops you then go back to see how she is two weeks later. She has not purchase the ear drops but instead asks you to get them for her freely. What can you do in this situation? Do you think people should be expected to pay for their own treatment? If so, why?

Greetings fellow VHTs. My regards to you Catherine and Bryan. This is my reply to todays question. If that lady comes and she did not buy the medicine but she wants me to get it for her instead, I tell her I can't afford it but she should try raise the money herself in order to improve herself. People shouldn't be forced to buy their own medicines, but because of their situation they have to buy it as they need it.

This is my reply to todays question - when I go back after 2 weeks and she didn't buy the medicine I tell her she didn't do a good thing because she is sick and she needs to improve her health. The more you delay the more money it costs. When you treat it earlier, you spend less money and you get cured very fast.

For the second question - people are supposed to buy medicine because the government health centres don't have medicine for complicated disease. The medicine in gvmt hc is for malaria. So when you have such a disease you need to buy your own. The government does not give it to our health centres so you just have to buy it.

Lastly they need to buy the medicine because it is their health - there are so many diseases affecting the community. If not attended to it might get worse. My regards to you all fellow VHTs in your villages. Thanks for serving the country. May god bless you as you tend to the patients.

Greetings VHTs, if I go back and find that she didn't buy the medicine and she asks for money from me to buy it I tell her we are just volunteers. We offer services to ensure you ae ok and don't get paid anything. I request her to go get money elsewhere and buy the medicine because your life is in your own hands. If you can't afford medicine, you are badly off and your going die. I request you to help yourself, get that medicine, as I personally don't have medicine to give. That is what I tell that person, but in a good way.

Good morning VHTs - thanks for the work. This is my reply to todays question. If I go back to her place and find that she didn't buy the medicine, and she then expects me to give it to her I can't afford it. I cannot afford the medicine, because the government can't afford it. So if the government can't afford it, how am I , a VHT meant to afford it? I tell her to do whatever it takes to get the money for the medicine in order to have good ears. I also tell her that if she delays there may be further damage to the ears and she may be unable to communicate to others.

You asked us should people buy medicine for themselves. My view is yes. People should buy it for themselves because the medicine might be so expensive so if we buy for them we might fail. Yet it is so bad to start something and we do not finish it so I think they should buy the medicine for themselves. Why? Me I want them to buy it for themselves cos people will be more careful. We are careless me inclusive. For example you give them free olive oil to put in the ears, but you go there and try to wash out the ear so when they buy it they will take the responsibility to make sure their money is not wasted. When we give it for free they can drop it on the road side even when they have not finished their doses. They throw the medicine - if we give for free they won't take it seriously. So I want them to buy it for themselves. That way they will be more responsible. Another thing when the person buys his or her own medicine it is properly prescribed and the money. So the person can also tell a friend that I bought the medicine for myself, it is not from the government or free of charge.
I refer her to the health centre of seeta nazigo to get treatment if she doesn't have anyone to buy her the medicine.

Question 2. When I find those people in my community, I encourage them and tell them they ain't alone with hearing problems. I also advise them that there are organizations that empower deaf people with technical skills in carpentry and tailoring using sign language. We have encountered such people in society and they are usually very good. That's the advise I can give. There are also schools that teach deaf people using sign language.

Thanks for today's work fellow VHTs and for answering the questions. Thanks Catherine and Bryan for the work you're doing for us. It's me Qiana and this is my reply to the first question. The reason as to why there are so many deaf people in Mukono district is because of the parents. They would get pregnant and refuse to go to the health centre. In case they fell sick, they always bought quinine and would swallow an overdose. At the time of birth, they would end up producing deaf children. Others would give birth to normal children but would treat children with quinine. My in-law's child is a victim. He had cerebral malaria and they treated him with quinine. He's now  deaf in senior one but uses sign language. Quinine was so common back in the days. Pregnant women were not allowed to use it though and were given fansidar instead. That's the reason as to why there are many deaf people. Whoever used quinine fell victim. Well done fellow VHTs. Forgive me my network is not good but I've replied to the question. As for today's question, in case I check in the 50 year old lady's ears and find nothing yet they itch, it means there are germs. We talked about that issue and were wondering the cause because a lot of people ask us. We said Catherine, Bryan and Andrew should give us the answer and the treatment for it. I know a man who has ash coming out of the ears and it also causes itching. The reason as to why they insert sticks in the ears is to ease the itching. I also had issues with mine before the washout and used to insert in sticks. Such sticks may damage the inner ear. I can only refer such a patient to specialists. That's my reply but the network is not good.

I greet you in the name of Jesus. My suggestions about this lady Annette; when I go there when she didn't buy the medicine, my job is to talk with her very well because she was supposed to buy the medicine to help her get out of the problem. So I tell her to look for all ways of buying that medicine. Then I show her the benefit of treating the illness, so I tell her if you delay the illness will get worse, treatment will become expensive. So I beg you to try as much as possible and buy the medicine. That is my suggestion.

Another question; you said what can you do in such a situation? Even though we are VHTs, we are counsellors too. The work of the counsellor is to share ideas so that that person can help herself to get out of the issue. The best idea is to talk with them very well and come up with a solutation, where to get the medicine so that they can get the treatment.

Another question was saying do you think people should buy medicines for themselves; it is true. The first reason is that in Uganda now there is a problem with medicine - it doesn't care about health. So someone has to buy medicine for themselves. Another thing is that when you use your money to buy medicine you use it as directed. But in most cases people become careless because they got it for free. They did not put any money from their pockets in - but if they use their money they can do things right. So I think people should buy medicine according to the way Uganda is. Even in Mulago nothing is free. That is my suggestion have a good day.

Good morning our coordinators - Bryan, Andrew and Catherine. Thanks be to God for keeping you - I also greet all our brothers and sisters for keeping you. Here are my answers. When I go to Annette's place, and find out she didn't buy the medicine that she was told to buy to stop itching the truth is when she asks me to buy it for her, I sit down with her then I explain to her that I examined you, I told you the issue, I told you what to do. So in that case I don't have the medicine. We are also not given such medicine from our coordinators so I request you to care about yourself and look for all possible ways if you don't have money - ask from your family members or friends such that they can help you to get that medicine; because when you delay the situation can get worse. The itching won't stop on the outer ear. It will also affect the inner part. When the illness gets worse - it gets expensive to treat. So I advise her to continue to look for ways to buy the medicine.

The next part - this is how I reply. The truth is, because we give a tax on everything we buy as you see todays government it shouldn't be that we buy medicine for ourselves because on everything - even the smallest thing we buy - we are taxed. So because we people who give tax we need the government to give us free medicine. But because our government has many loop holes people are forced to buy medicine for themselves. If you wait to demonstrate and protest, most of us will die by the time they decide to provide it. But we pay tax, and the tax could be use to buy medicine to help the people. In that situation because the government don't do it in time people have to buy medicine for themselves.

Another part, which says should people buy their own medicines? The truth is when someone doesn't hustle to get something, they don't appreciate the value of that item. But for a person who has worked hard to get money to get something or to get money a person will always be so careful about how to use that money. So the person will say I worked hard for this money so I can't play around. But if a person doesn't know where something came from they don't take any care or doesn't take any responsibility. Another thing - people who give you free medicine care about your life more than you. If you give it free its like you are forcing things on them - so let them love their live first. That is why they have to buy the medicine themselves so they know what it is like to go through to get the money. They need to know the cost of the medicine - if they don't know the cost they will use it poorly. If they know it is 100,000 they will use it wisely.

I greet you my fellow VHTs. As we were all aware, steroid drops can help itching in ears. So Annette, I would advise her buy that medicine and after 1 week when I go back and find she didn't buy the medicine and asks to get the medicine for free. I tell her I can't do that for free. Instead she has to look for money so that she can get the medicine. What I inform her, they wrote the medicine but it's not there at the health centre so we have to buy it and I also think people should buy medicine for themselves because it is their life and the government can't manage to treat 40 million people. It doesn't have the ability to get that medicine. That is why you see the medicine at the health centre - for example you see it at the health centre for 3 months doesn't even last for a month at the health centre. So that is what causes people to get upset. They just examine them and write them a script for a medicine to be bought elsewhere. So I tell her you go buy that medicine and also people have to care about their life. They shouldn't wait for the government, because the government is you and me. It doesn't have that ability - that is why private hospitals or pharmacies are so many in the country to help the government. We have to pay some money so people should know life is more important. They should also take into consideration that when they get money, put some aside for treatment in case they fall sick, That is my suggestion for today.
Greetings Bryan, for the work you're doing. I have a client with a perf and pus, they need the medicine. Please send me the medicine for this. I will take a photo of the child.

Greetings my fellow VHTs thanks for the work your doing - Andrew, Bryan Catherine. About todays case that lady Annette about the medicine they directed her to buy - the steroid drops. If she was directed to buy the medicine and we find out she didn’t buy it either because she didn't have money or wants it for free I think we counsel her. She shouldn't take her life for granted. Because the illness will become greater. So I sit with her. I advise her to look for the money in all ways so she can go buy that medicine. Not every medicine is there in the government health centres. We always find whenever we go to government health centres we don't find certain medicines so we have to go to private pharmacies. So I sit with her and advise her with counselling. The next question,  I say yes, Buying medicine isn't bad because there is some medicine that is so expensive that even the government can't give it to everyone in Uganda. Therefore buying medicine is not bad - it is a responsibility for a person who is sick to take care or her life and to use the medicine and not waste it. By working hard, getting money they don't waste it.

Greetings members thanks for todays work. Those in pain - I pray you are healed. The question was saying after telling Annette, the situation is like this - based on her age. She is in her 50s - her source of income might be low. If I have money I can buy medicine for her. Then I inform her I don't have enough but I bought you the first dose. Another thing I do - I refer her to the hospital to see that she gets the medicine. The next question said, do you think ppl should buys medicines for themselves, I say yes because they need to care about themselves before the illness gets worse. Another thing - it helps them to be responsible for their lives. Because if they keep waiting for something for free, they don't care enough. Yet, the illness gets worse. Another thing, is because in the government hospitals the medicine is not there. When you reach there they tel you to buy the medicine yourself. But on the other side, it is in the governments responsibility to protect and look after its people. Another thing is that people shouldn't buy medicine for themselves because they pay tax.

Greetings VHTs thanks for the work - my answer for todays question, for what I tell her is I don't have the medicine. I can't give it out. When she is not able to buy the medicine - if I have sme money I try help her. But when I also don’t have, I say, because of your life try as hard as possible to ask from your friends or relatives to get some money so you can buy the medicine. Because if you don't treat, the illness will get worse. It might even affect the ear drum. Also the government has not cared for the people - like the hospitals aren't good at all. But other governments, when they care about health and put medicine in the hospitals the people don't suffer. But todays government has not helped at all. It wants people to buy everything for themselves yet some people don't have money and even if you are working the money isn't enough because you are using it on many things. So it hasn;'t helped us - even when you go to the hospital the medicine isn't enough , but I don't discourage her. I keep encouraging, I follow up, I ask her if she has a little money I try top up with my own so she can get the medicine. That is my response.

Greetings my fellow VHTs thanks for all the work you're doing - all the VHTs. Isabella - sorry for the problems. Bryan, Catherine, Andrew thanks for all the work and the knowledge your giving us. About that patient, when I reach and find out she didn't buy the medicine or she doesn't have money or when she doesn't have anyone to buy for her and when I also don't have money to give her I tell her according to todays situation you have to care about your life. She might have a friend, who might be willing to lend money to help. I also advise don't resort to local medicine. She can try do some work to get money like weaving mats to try get money out of it.
Ok Francesca, who do you think is responsible?
Thanks Nora

Ok Dorothy, but according to you, do you think people should buy medicines for themselves or it is the governments responsibility?
That is good, but what if the patients are many?
Thank you Qiana, but you haven’t answered todays case.
Ok Isabella thank you.
Thank you Harriet, so it means the government is the one responsible to provide that medicine, but because of the situation people end up buying the medicine?
Ok Karl, so it means the government is the one responsible, but it doesn't have that?
So it means it is better for people to buy medicines themselves. Thanks for your suggestion Gordon.
You will refer to hospital but what if she doesn’t have money?

Ok Mr. Matthew, but as you see, who should buy the medicine?

The second question. I counsel the patient and I tell her to buy the medicine. And also take it in the prescribed time and also eating something before taking the medicine. Also not being so stressed. Because such things happen. Also I tell her about clinics where she can get the medicine. The different is she is the one to buy the medicine and I will get to know which day she will buy the medicine. That is my suggestion.

I also tell her this. That life is expensive these days, so you have to buy the medicine. The government doesn't care about us, though they bring the medicine in hospitals - it isn't enough. So you have to invest in your life. So you have to buy your medicine, so that you can be alive. The government hasn't helped us - it is just taking from us. We have to invest in everything, especially life. If you don't invest in life - you will die. It is true we have to buy the medicine and take it in time after eating so that the illness doesn't get worse. And for us to stay longer.

Good morning my fellow VHTs, thanks for the work we are doing for the country. Welcome back from the church for those who went for prayers. The ones who I sending you greetings is Qiana and welcome back.

Greetings VHTs; there is a question which had remained that Catherine had asked us - the one saying who is supposed to buy the medicine. First of all I greet you all. Those who wee there yesterday in the training, thank you so much Catherine, and also our coordinator Andrew and Mr. Bryan and also other doctors who gave us the last training. Both of them. They all did a great job for the country because it was all about health but I thank the VHTs who came from far. If I am to respond to the other question the patient has to try as much as possible to buy the medicine, because in the government hospitals - sometimes there is no medicine other than Panadol which can't heal her problem. Let us see if we don't have another question - let me keep scrolling.
I will give feedback on all the above messages once they have been translated. Sorry for the delay VHTs.

Happy Easter to you all and thanks for the good work. I am going to arrange an in-person training day at Seeta Nazigo in 2 weeks time to deliver more training for you all and to go over all of the answers for things in the case group.
Happy Easter too Dr.

Now for today's question of Annette asking for treatment for her itching ears, I personally refer her to the health centre to get pain killers. They can also examine her and if they have no medicine for her problem, they can write it down for her to get it from any pharmacy. If she insists on getting antibiotics I explain to her that I examined her ears and there's nothing like pus or perforations. Such ears don't need antibiotics and if we apply them she may get some side effects because it would be the wrong medication. I strengthen her and advise her to go to the health centre for medicine that can stop that itching. In case they don't have it, she can get it from the pharmacy after them writing it down. That's my answer to today's question. Thank you so much.

Greetings my fellows. Now for today's question, I cannot give Annette antibiotic drops even if she insists. I don't and I explain to her that it's because her ears are normal. I also see no treatment that could be given to her because it's just itching and I have no medication for it but I can tell her about some of the causes like too much heat, wax and fungus infections. I then refer her to the health centre for further examination. She can get the treatment from there because I personally don't have it.

Good morning fellow members. Thanks for today and yesterday's work. We discovered yesterday's that Annette has itching which could be as a result of a skin infection. Antibiotic drops cannot work for her in this case but if she insists, I refer her to a doctor in order not to upset her. The doctor can give her panadols to ease the itching and deworming tablets because it's possible she may be having worms causing the problem. Another thing I can do not to upset her is to send her to specialists and if they discover something, they can let her know and I get her the medicine.

Greetings to you all. My name is Gordon. Now if I find that lady Annette from Makata with itching ears and she insists on me giving her antibiotic drops yet on examining there was no problem inside, I don't give them to her. I refer her to a bigger hospital for examination. We looked at some of the causes of itching yesterday like fungal infections, too much heat and too much wax. I cannot give her any medication but rather refer her. That's what I have to say. It's me Gordon from Makata.

Greetings our fellow VHTs. Sorry Hadijja but God cares. After checking Miss Annette like we saw yesterday and find there's nothing in her ears but she insists on me giving her antibiotics, I explain to her that it's not necessary because there's neither a wound nor pus. I explain to her some of the causes like inserting sticks and then refer her to specialists. She may be having the fungal infections we talked about or even allergy.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for the work and for replying to the questions. The reason as to why you haven't been hearing from me is because my charger had a fault. But this is my reply to the question. The advice I can give Annette is not to use the antibiotic drops because they are only used when someone has pus or perforations in their ears. I advise her to keep her ears clean and in case there's wax, we can put oil to soften it and then do an ear washout after 5 days. If the itching insists, I tell her to visit the health centre for further examination. That's my opinion on today's question.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for the work you're doing. Thanks to those who have replied to the question. I won't differ so much from my fellows on the issue of Annette who has itching ears. Truth is some people feel like they know a lot more than everyone else so they can push one into doing something that may cause damage to them. If she insists she needs the antibiotic drops yet I checked her ears and found nothing, truth is I don't give them to her. If you apply medicine without any disease it becomes poison and I cannot give someone poison that would be harmful to them. I explain to her that I can't give her the medicine because it's not necessary for her condition and then refer her to specialists to find out the cause. That's how I can explain to her personally.

Greetings fellow VHTs and thanks for the work. This is my reply to the question. If Miss Annette insists on me giving her antibiotics, I tell her it will bring problems for her since her condition doesn't need them. I tell her I would if she had pus or any other discharge, or had a perforation on the ear drum. The advice I can give her is to go to seeta Nazigo health centre for further examination and treatment. I personally don't have the treatment for it.
If I examine the ears of the 50 year old woman and find no wax but she says they itch, I advise her not to use sticks in them. Another thing is she may be having infections in her blood.

What I see in the picture is someone's head with an abnormal shape of the pinna. I know it as microtia. How I can handle the condition is by letting the person know it's possible to be operated if they're fine with it. And then I refer them to a specialist for further examination.
Well done Dorothy this is absolutely correct. Do all other VHTs agree? If you do you don't need to reply to the question as this is the correct answer.
If you have any other questions about this case please let us know.

How's your day fellow VHTs? Thanks for all the work. Thank God for getting us through the holiday and for keeping us alive. This is my reply to today's question as Hadijja. I can see a head with an ear that has a swollen pinna. That disease is called haematoma. When I find such a patient, I refer them to a specialist because they need surgery. Greetings and I wish you well as you reply to the question. May God be with you.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thanks for today's work. I have seen the question too but I won't differ from my sister Dorothy. The way she's replied is what I was expecting the answer to be. Nora thank you for your answer however as Dorothy correctly observed this is called "microtia". The pinna is abnormally shaped following birth. Microtia will be in the section on outer ear disorders.

Greetings fellow VHTs. I can see a swelling on the pinna. Such conditions become serious if you don't attend to them early. If I see such a patient, I refer them to a specialist because they need surgery and as soon as possible.

Greetings fellow VHTs. I had travelled and just got to see this question. When I see that picture, it looks like the pinna is abnormal. Hi VHTs, for todays question please say what you think the problem is with the above ear, and how you want to manage it. Thank you.

How have you been VHTs? Thanks for the work. I was unable to answer yesterday's question but I'll answer it now. According to what I see in the picture, I would ask that person if they have any pain or hearing loss. If they say they don't have any I ask if they would like to be referred because it  requires money. I personally don't think that ear can be fixed and put it in its right form like a normal ear. I think God naturally created her like that. She was born that way. But if they ask for a referral, I would go ahead and refer them. If there's no other problem like pus, pain, tinnitus I just tell her God created you like that. That's my reply to yesterday's picture.

And this is my answer to today's picture. When I see that person I refer them to ENT specialists for surgery and further information because they know more than I do. But I personally know nothing so I just refer them. That's what I have to say about today's picture.

When I look at today's ear in the picture that has been given to us I see a hole behind the pinna. I remember they told us if the skin of the ear drum grew from inside, the behind part of the ear looks like that which is called cholesteatoma. That's what I see to day.

Greetings to you all VHTs and our bosses. I am sorry I didn't answer yesterday's question because my phone was dead. Thanks to those who replied. Now for today's question I am being asked what I can see in the picture. I see an ear that has a hole behind the pinna and we were told that hole is called post auricular fistula. What I can do for a patient with that condition is to refer them to specialists. I personally don't have the treatment for such an ear. That's how I've answered that question.
How I can handle that condition is by referring the patient to specialists. They can decide what to do for them.

Greetings fellow VHTs. Thank for all the work you're doing Catherine, Bryan, Andrew and fellow VHTs. I welcome you back Catherine and Bryan wherever you were.
